text: Tap @ Jolly Pumpkin, Ann Arbor - Hazy orange, thick white head Dry, crispy, caramel malts. Spicey and orangey and citrusy.
Thanks SoLan! Sweet coriander nose, hazy dark sunset/gold.  Spices hit up front, softens out quickly from the rounded chewy body, finishes dry from the spice blend, little peppery.

Orange and hazy under a voluminous head which fades much like a spluttering volcano. Thankfully, there is no lava involved, just a bounteous nose which demands my full attention. Tartness nibbles the front and tickles the back as all Jolly Pumpkin beers do, and I love every minute of it. Sour lemons and limes delight while grapefruit and tangerines accompany toasted bread. Dewdrops glimmer atop flower petals, and I immediately think of candied flower petals decorated with a light dusting of powdered sugar. Throw a bit more lemon zest in there and voila, lemon drops for those who love to pucker. Dried straw is a subtle accent in the background along with faint green grass esters. Lovely. Being bottle-conditioned, I rightfully expect and receive a soft frothy mouthfeel which lifts her body and cleanses my palate for each flavorful quaff. Her sour side is more bark than bite, allowing gentle flower petals, grassy esters, and dry straw to appropriately dazzle. Oranges and apricots lay naked on a plate before me, their discarded skins bittering the finish. Lemon and lime zest mingles with tart apricot skins in the middle while her Bretty side slowly dries my palate. Shadows of dry hop cones, dry straw, and dry flower petals whisper in my lingering breath. Sweet up front, she leads me into lemon-lime zest with floral and Bretty esters coming last. Complex yet simple, sessionable yet contemplative, Luciernaga maintains her effervescence through the last quaff.


Its been a few months since I tasted the Luciernaga Firefly from Jolly Pumpkin, but like the good little beer geek that I am, there is a bottle set aside at home in a relatively dark and definitely cool place. Maybe sometime Ill crack her open on a gorgeous sunny day with blue skies and nary a cloud in sight. Sounds fantastic to me.

On tap at Ginger Man NY 
 Aroma  mild nose , frontal malts , slight roast on sides. 6+ 
 Appearance:  mild haze on amber looking ale , large creamy top. Good lace was noted. 
 Flavour and Palate:  mild , bit earthy sides , soft oily texture with herbal hints. Nice easy going brew. Late bitterness. Quiet refreshing.

Bottle. Pours a nice amber color, off white head. Aroma is quite funky, classic jolly pumpkin. It also has many aromas of peppery hops, spicy yeast, definately spice/herb forward, with a hint of citrus and grain. Taste is sour almost enough to be out of category in belgian ale.

This is a well-made beer but didnt live up to expectations.  Too much spicing and not enough wood for my taste, particularly in JP beers, which I normally love.  The present oak and funk are quite good, but the funny spice just steals the show a bit.  Medium dry.  Some good light grain notes.  Enjoyable beer but there are much better from JP.  I have a bottle, so Ill revisit this one eventually.

Capped 750 from the Co-op in Davis, CA. Pours dark amber with a 4 finger foamy beige head. Mild sour and earthy aromas. Medium plus body with foamy carbonation. Flavor is earthy, mildly sour, a little oaky, and tends to have a "brown ale" malt base. Its yeasty/spice and it hits on the tongue edges. All that and it finishes rather bitter. Tends to leave oak all over. Mildly astringent. Good ale. Cause its real ale.

750 that blew up when opened. Plenty left to drink though.  Hazy dark copper with a huge white head. Nose is citric, lemony with a nice funk/horseblanket odor. Very effervescent. Taste is the same but smoothed down a bit. This seemed to have aged a bit but is still very flavorable and drinkable. Great brett taste but not overwhelming. Not much of an alcohol presence.  Good stuff here.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: 2007 bottle from bbb.   consumed summer, 2010. thanks, mike!   pours a hazy, dirty brown with a bright medium tan head.  spotty lace.  quite spicy with a light lemony lactic tartness.  also a bit of bready candy.  maybe a bit past its prime.   but neat to try some aged jolly pumpkin.

Draft..Clear golden pour , small white head , sparse lacing . Aroma of fruit and Brett funkiness .  Flavor is light hop , citrus and some spiciness . Light caramel , tart with woody notes. Very dry hoppy finish .

Served on tap at PB TapRoom. The appearance is a darker orange hue. There is a solid grainy wood flavor with some wild yeast  characteristics. Some coriander and other spices too. The mouth is really drying.

On tap. Hazy medium-dark orange-amber with a thick, rocky, light tan head. Some spice, tasted malt, and a faint tartness in the aroma. Flavor is dry maltiness, soft hops spice, and a slight hint of fruity tartness. Nice light, dry body with simple structure that holds up dutifully but not heroically.

750 ml bottle shared with jsprime, his bottle. bottled 4-22-10. pours hazed golden with a big white head, great retention and lacing. aroma of yeast driven spice, floral and fruity as well. the flavour is balanced betwen the pale malt and hops. there is more hop flavour and less funk then the other JPs ive had. the finish is tight and dry. nice beer.

Pours a hazy blonde with a big head and some lace. The aroma is hoppy and earthy with some fruity notes, reminds me a bit of Orval in this sense. The flavor has a nice character of fruity hopes and a mild malt sweetness, but the beer is dominantly dry. There is a very mild tartness here but generally the beer is dominated by a blend between some spicy yeast notes and pleasant hop bitterness.
Draft. Pours hazy gold, with a thin white head, spotty lacing. Nose is orange, white pepper, funk, coriander. Flavours of mandarin orange, Asian spices, funk, yeast. Good.

Big thanks to Sarah for sharing this one!

A-pours the standard golden amber color, hazy, with a slightly off white head.

S-the nose has a nice light belgian yeast to it, notes of spice to it, citrusy hop aromas of mango and orange.

T-the flavor has a nice belgian yeast, slightly earthy, great spice to it with a nice sweetness behind, citrusy flavors of mango, hints of acidity, some bitter grapefruit, light lingering bitterness in the finish.

M-light to medium body, syrupy texture, soft with a hint of grain in the feel towards the back, good carbonation (could use more but still enough to balance) with a dry finish.

D-this is quite nice, great beer with a fantastic balance to it and a nice amount of complexity.  spice, citrus, acidity, earthy, yeasty, well put together.

750ml into snifter. Pours golden orange with frothy white head. Sweet malts on the nose followed by barnyard funk. Mouthfeel is rich and smooth with lots of carbonation. Falvor is of sweet malts and belgian yeast with a hint of spiciness and a minty flavor left on the palate. Delicious brew.

Location: Draft at Jimmys 43, 7/17/10


Aroma: The nose has some sweet malts, a touch of spice, light funk, and some of that typical JP yeast

Appearance: Pours into the glass a hazy orange-amber pour with a rocky white head a top it

Flavor: Taste has a little fruity sweetness, funk, spice, Belgian yeast, and light hops

Palate: The body is medium, it has a fairly soft carbonation, and slightly dusty finish

Overall Impression: 
Overall, I enjoyed this one.  A nice, if fairly typical Jolly Pumpkin beer.  It has a pretty solid complexity too it.  While this may not be the best thing Ive had in this style, but I did enjoy it.

750ml bottle from K&L.  Pours a cloudy amber color with a large white head and decent lacing.  The aroma is nice if restrained.  Slightly fruity and Belgian with green apple and spice.  Funky basement smells as well with wild yeast evident.  Flavor is fairly funky and wild but not too sour.  Slight malty sweetness balances the mild tartness.  Green apples and grains of paradise along with Belgian yeast notes in addition to your usual Jolly Pumpkin yeast.  Medium-bodied and smooth with a good carbonation level.  A solid ale overall, but not one of the more impressive offerings Ive had from this brewery.

Pours a dark golden haze with lots of liveliness of running fizz throughout the glass. Smells of tart wheat and fresh sour apples. Their is a wonderful sour/tartness of fresh fruit (apples). Good balance of hoppiness and a dry crisp finish. Great offering from JP.
Nose was very herbal with hints of pepper and spice. moderate sourness, hints of vinegar, mostly just tart and clean flavor profile.

On tap at Rattle N Hum.  Pours a hazy browned golden amber with large dense white head.  Soft classic Jolly Pumpkin funk, wheat and some fuzzy almost plastic tones.  Wheat and funk on a medium body, estery yeast coming through.  Smooth and silky, fuzzy hay flavors, more gently funky soft hay on the finish.  Yummy.

Pours a cloudy golden color with a large pillowy off-white head.  Aroma is light aged earthy and floral hops, light citrus, and belgian spice.  Taste is lightly tart up front and has a dry spicy finish.  Good but sometimes seems to close to La Roja and other JP beers.

Thanks for sharing this with me, bro!  And to top it off, its my 1000th rating.  Any chance to drink a JP beer is usually a good thing, and this brew is no different.  Pours a  cloudy amber color with thick, frothy, off-white head with big gobs of lacing.    Aroma is funky brett, light coriander, citrus, light green apple, and basement.  Taste is light citrus, brett, and light yeast notes up front, and in the swallow comes a bit of a more sour and tart taste with a bit of a spicy finish.  Another solid JP offering.

750 ml bottle poured into a tulip.  Color of apple cider with big frothy white head.  Aroma of sour apples, funky bretty, citrus, and bready yeast.  Taste is lightly sweet and moderately sour.  Mouthfeel is a bit thin, not as rich as Id expect.  Overall quenching and tasty, a nice brew!

Tap @ Belmont Station during Puckerfest...  Poured amber with a white head.  Wood-like, oaky with hints of melon, honey, and a yeast tanginess.  Acidic and dry on the palate.  Lots of lactic notes with even bananas, coriander, and a malt balance.  Although the grains of paradise created an exceptional flavor profile for this beer, I think it really distracted from the yeast and tart qualities.

on tap at The Porter in ATL.  Arrived to the table a deep golden color with a 1 finger white fluffy head.  Really nice funky Brett aroma with some spices, tart apples and some wood.  Medium dry body with more funk, light fruit notes and subtle hops.  Dry tart, spice yeasty finish.  Very nice!

A real lively, heavily spiced brew. Real tasty and all the intangibles are off the charts. With the color and the gigantic tight head this was one of the most gorgeous brews Ive ever seen. Awesome on all levels.
Draft at Brick Store.  Pours amber with thick, frothy white head.  Aroma is just like Orval to me.  Nice funky nose.  Taste has Brett and spices.  Very good.

On tap at the Ann Arbor cafe.  Pours hazy amber with a large off-white head.  Has a tart lemony citrus aroma, a little fruitiness like apple.  Flavor is again the lemon tartness, funky, with some spice and bitter hops.  Dry.  Very nice.
Sample at the HSC Sour tasting on 6/19/10. Pours clear gold with a medium off-white head. Very familiar JP funky nose with some tart citrus and sweet malt. Tart citrus with funk and a bitter finish.

Clear amber pour with a massive white head that rises and stays like a miniature mountain range. The aroma holds an excellent Orval-like bretty citrus character, as well as some yeasty dough and wheat grain. A firm spicy note also comes forward as the brew warms- coriander and clove with a hint of floral hop. The flavor holds a pronounced dry earthy brett character with notes of juicy nectar fruits, orange peel, grassy hay, and herbage. The palate is lively in its effervescence with a pillowy, creamy texture that finishes quite dry. A delicious winner for sure.

Sample at the HSC Sour Beer Tasting on 06/19/2010: This brew is a hazy orange color with a medium thin and fizzy off-white head that diminishes steadily. Stringy lacing on the glass. Aroma of brett, yeast and citrus. Medium body with flavors of spices and yeast, fruit and a bit of funk. The finish is citrusy with a yeast aftertaste. Pretty good overall.

750ml bottle from Bev4less. Pours a cloudy copper color with a medium white head that has good retention and some sticky lacing. The aroma is funky with sour green apples, Belgian yeast and spices (probably coriander). The taste is similarly funky with sour fruits, wood, spices, some yeast and malty biscuit. The palate is smooth and creamy with lively carbonation. The finish is long and dry. Overall: A very unique ale, but I couldnt drink this every day, its a bit of an acquired flavor and I can take it only in small doses.

750 ml bottle. Pours a hazy coppery gold with a moderate white head that lasted through mid-glass and left partial lace.  Very pleasant sour aroma that also has some floral notes along with some very mild lemon.  The flavor is equally sour but not overdone.  The tartness is spot-on.  Coriander is very noticeable in the flavor along with some very mild oak and lemon.  Effervescent and bright on the palate.   Very enjoyable!

(750ml batch 387/388) clear orange with great lacing and great lasting head. Nose of apricot, tart fruit, cherries and light funk, champagne. Taste grain, tart grapes, unsweet fruit, very dry, tart, carbonated finished.

Thanks to thirdeye11 for sharing this bottle at our recent sour tasting.

Batch 387/388. The beer pours a clear medium-dark orange color with a large cream-colored head. The aroma is oranges, yeast, pineapple, mango and some tartness. The flavor is citrus fruit with some yeast and low-medium tartness. There are also some spices similar to white pepper. There is a little funk as well. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2012 750ml from Winooski. Batch 3 Bottled 4-28-10.
Appearance : Slightly hazy amber small head. Some lacing.

Aroma : Lots of funk, barnyard. Spices with brett. Light herbal hops light malt. Really nice funk. Nice tartness.

Taste : Dry and funky. Brett with nice barnyard funk. Basement notes. Slightly tart. Finish funky, spicy and slightly bitter.

Palate : Fizzy carbonation.

Overall : Great stuff, awesome funky notes. Great funk too. Quite drinkable. I could use a bit less spices. Nice light tartness. Really enjoyable. Maybe not as good as my first rating but still really nice. Rating stays the same. 

750ml bottle at a tasting thanks to MartinT
Apparence : Hazy amber with a small head. 

Aroma : Very wild and dry. Some brett and some bitter hops. Very barnyard and a bit tart.

Taste : Dry hops, a bit sweet and a bit tart. Barnyard and wild. Finish is bretty and barnyard. Very dry also. A bit mineral also. Finish is also a bit tart.

Overall : Awesome dry and barnyard nose. Nice taste also, well balanced and not overpowering. Very nice beer, quite drinkable and VERY dry. I think I like this one more than Orval. May 24th 2010. 9,3,9,3,17;4.1
UPDATED: JUN 5, 2010 bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  deep amber pour with a thick cream head.  nice on the palate.  flavor is funky wood, brett, light tartness in the end as well.

750 ml bottle; thanks to RCL for the trade; pours clear light copper with 2 fizzy white head; floral aromas with a mix of fruits, candy malts, white sugary and yeasty spices; soft, light, fizzy mouthfeel with an almost bretty funkiness to it; apples, pears, oranges; soft and subtle with a rich bouquet of flavors and mild sourness; a great Belgian ale that doesnt disappoint
Pours amber with a white head. Aroma is malt, fruity, horseblanket,barnyard, dry, tart and some pepper. Flavour is malt, acidic, perfume, fruit, tart and pepper. Complex beer.

From TheCheeseMan via trade.  The pour was a muddled light brown color with a powerful white head and tons of lacing.  The aroma was slightly sour, a bit of funk and plenty of pepper and spice (coriander I suppose).  The flavor was a combination of spices and a touch of sour.   A nice mouthfeel and it went down easy, just wasnt blown away by this one.

Bottle with Craig, who kindly supplied this beer (cheers mate) consumed at my gaff, day two tasting 09-04-10    Pours hazy amber. The aroma is dusty hops with some lemony wafts, this is also replicated in the mouth. Busy carbonation, refreshing, fruity, tingly sourness, good stuff.    A7 A4 F7 P4 Ov14  3.6
bottle at fins ... another gusher ... hazy amber ... sweet funky barnyard ... soft fruity toffee ... little lemon... nice fruity

Bottle shared by the notorious footy -- thanks!  Pours an apricot color with a frothy beige head.  Smells sour -- loaded with JP spices and lemon juice.  Tastes strangely tart and musty with further spice, cardboard, and underripe apples.  Not my bag.
Cloudy apricot pour.  Light head.  I get orange marmalade, some vinegar, wood and apple juice.  Flavor is spicy, dry and woody. Some light sweetness in the background.

Bottle from Kris Wines, London. Ruddy brown with a soapy head and some sediment. Potent brettanomyces aroma, softened by sweet maltiness. Sweet maltiness meeting dry brettanomyces. Subtle spices. Rather than Grand Cru I would say more like a gentle Orval or a saison.

750 ml. bottle from Greens. 387/388 batch. Very fluffy head. Light to medium brown color with a dark orange hue. Looks pretty good, considering the fluffy head and color. Head lasts quite some time. Wow, a nice and pungent sweet sour apple aroma. Lots of sour and brett goodness seem to be hitting my nostrils. Ah... a nice pungent sour/brett aroma is enough to get a good vote from me. Would have given it a higher aroma score if there was some balance in terms of sweet aromas, but the sour/brett just take over. Damn, as I was hoping it wouldnt be this thing has an incisive carbonation bite. Due to the carbonation bite the sour apple and brett arent coming through as much as I hope they would. There is an apple tart flavor lingering on the tongue, but it isnt THAT pronounced. Subtle wood flavor is coming through as the beer warms. The wood flavor isnt that noticeable, but I am getting touches out it while drinking this thing. The beer has some nice qualities, but could be better, especially knowing what Jolly Pumpkin is capable of.

750, square-shouldered, with a cap. Not the elongated neck 750. Anyway, this was a full-kitchen-towel geyser on opening. Nice popping hiss, then a rapid rush of tiny bubbles all over the kitchen counter. Smelled fantastic in doing it, though. And, man, best label ever. Pours, when it pours, a cloudy dark amber with toffee highlights at the edges. Floatie chunks pretty prevalent. Big creamy eggy white head. Not much lace. Creamy, spicy, white-peppery nose (that would be the coriander and grains of paradise). The promised hops arent really there, but theres a little tangy plum note. Fizzy, creamy medium body. Leaves a spicy tingle on your lips and the roof of your mouth. Mild plummy mid-palate under a big blast of spicy coriander and grains of paradise...which I assume to be what are causing the intense white pepper flavor profile. Dry, hot white peppery finish. Interesting enough to overcome the problems of imbalance, but, wow, imbalance is not to be denied here. Needs some serious tweaking to attain cohesion.

Bevuta in un noto locale di Roma, birra interessante, non entusiasmante, dal colore arancio-ramato torbido, ha una schiuma chiara piuttosto lunga. al gusto traspare subito un forte agrumato, con note di mela, poi più dolce ed equilibrata. secca e decisa grazie alle note di frutta, ha un corpo non particolarmente pieno.

pours orange hue with thick off-white/golden head.
aroma, coriander, wood/oak, yeasty and tropical fruit nose.
flavor, wood elements, light spices, grain of paradise give the beer a mild peppery profile that is most delectable and not overpowering. Blends nicely with some of the fruit tartness that give it a somewhat tropical; mango mouthfeel, finish has some lemon elements, prickly wood palate.
This one had some age on it, and it drank superbly well.

Light amber colorm with a huge head.... bottle actually overflowed with foam upon opening, even though it was kept cold.  Big pillowy head in the glass.  Aroma is really nice... mostly spice and subtle funk, as is usually for a JP beer.  Taste is clean, evenly balanced hops, malt and funk, but with a very low-carbonated mouthfeel.  Bubbles are huge, effervescent ones.  Really interesting and enjoybale beer overall, but not as much going on here as in the La Roja ort Bam Biere.

Batch 387/388.  Clear golden orange and a typical JP lumpy rocky puffy sticky off white foam.  Bretty aroma and oak waft up, spicy hoppiness.  Taste is dry, funky, light malt sweetness, mixed florals, toast, spiciness.
Pours with a pillowy white head - smells of sour fruits.  Tart and effervescent mouth feel. Much like a mort subite. Not my favorite style but nice.

From Voldby, DK.
Bottled, 211109.
Amber with small head. Aroma sour. Flavor is malt on sour wood notes. Roasted malt and spices

65cl bottle at a christmas party.
bottle opened as a major gusher, and i wetted 3 ppl at the table whom rushed to the kitchen to get dried up. half the bottle stayed inside the bottle so i managed to rate it.
aroma is flowery, slighthy sour, citrussy, mild, nice faint wheaty.
flavor is sourish, citrussy, wheaty, brett?, woody character
quite tasty beer.
6th June 2008. Sourish amber beer. Pretty dry. Faint hint of orange. Spicy and very drinkable.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2011 Bottle. 25.4 oz. Split with Braden. Pours deep brownish amber with a thick, beige head. Aroma of spice, malt, hops, malt, clove, and hints of vanilla. Full bodied with a tangy, spicy finish. Great Beglian ale.

Re-rate: 12/31/11

Bomber split with Vinnie and Sean. Pours a chestnut orange with a thick, creamy, supple beiege head. Lacing is frothy and consistent. Aroma of green apple, hazelnuts, musty hops, soft hay, and some very subtle malty hints. Tastes like a fresh granny smith apple with some malt softness in the finish. Mouthfeel is tender and silky with some tart and a bit of pucker. This beer is truly something special and incredibly enjoyable. Excellent all around.
Im not going to lie, I was a little drunk when I opened this one. From what I can remember it was yeasty with a spicy/citrus finish.
Pours a hazy orange with beige head.  Aroma of yeast, spice, grass, malt.  Similar taste.  A citric bitter finish.  Not a big fan of this one.
Pours a fizzy, lasting ring of beige head with a hazy, copper-orange body.  Grass, zest, yeast, cherry candy aroma.  Flavor is the same as the aroma but with a vegetal, sour bite and somewhat muted.
Hazy orange, big frothy white head. Aroma is gum, lemon, sweet fruit and a slight tartness. Taste is more lemon and some hop bitterness along with funky yeast. Medium body with rich carbonation.

Bottle (batch 387/388): Nice thick head on the pour. Hazy orange brown color. Smells a little Nice salty spice flavor. A touch of vinegar as well. I like the flavor. Pretty good. Like the label too. Nice attempt at a Belgian

Bottle batch 387/388. Sampled at the Butters Last Supper tasting. Hazy orange pour with good white head and sticky lacing. Nose is sweaty socks, that have only been worn for a few hours though, a little white pepper, and hint of lemon zest. Flavor has a lot of citric acidity, with coriander, and  a perfumy hops. Very refreshing crisp palate. Reminds me of a tasty saison. This is the type of beer I would want to take a bath in.

Bottle (batch 387/388): Effervescent hazy deep orange with a dense lacing tan that retains. Very complex aroma- dry & spicy brett (Brux), leather and rustic, a soft prune note, nutmeg, dried orange peel, and a soft dry oak presence. Crisp frothy feel. Very dry flavor. Slightly citric and dusty with a minerally presence and a rustic layer of leather covering up some citric/grassy hop notes. The flavor isnt as complex as the outstanding aroma. Has some spicy/tannic apple skins as well. A great dry Belgian Ale.
UPDATED: MAY 17, 2011 Nice herb-y aroma.  Nice golden / dark color.  A lot of spice and yeast flavors.  Quite refreshing and almost bubbly.

I have enjoyed every Jolly Pumpkin beer I have tasted and this was no exception. In fact, this was probably my favorite after Biere De Mars. The color was a cloudy orange, hazy. The head was viciously strong and took a while to settle. it looked like whipped fluff sitting on top of the brew. The smell was funk! Funky, funky, with some sour vinegar and mustiness but I liked it! The taste was also sour, fruity, dry, delicious. The Jolly Pumpkin beers are kinda costly but they really are well made beers. Excellent!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-31-2007 15:46:48

Batch 296/297.  Typical JP gusher.  Pours a murky-coppery-gold color with a massive (and growing), off-white, fluffy, rocky head which takes some time to settle but does eventually leave a mostly lasting, small, pillowy layer and sporadic, Belgian lace all over.  Nose is pleasant and unique; sourish notes of lemons and orange peel, wet earth, some funky basement yeast, overripe pineapple, sweet caramel, a bit of allspice, light buttery biscuits, and hints at horse blanket.  Flavor starts out with a sour lemon flash but then mellows bringing some wet earth, pineapple, light dry caramel, orange peel, light white pepper, funky/basement yeast, and a moderately light hop bitterness into the finish.  Palate is medium, light on the tongue yet coating, drying a touch, and lively.  The long, lightly dry finish has the spice notes disappearing and leaving some light horse blanket, basement yeast, earthy/bitter hops, and an underlying lemon sourness lingering to the end.  Another really good beer from JP, nothing exceptional but very well put together with the typical tartness/sourness you get in almost all of their beers.  Incredibly drinkable and refreshing with a perfect balance of spice, sour notes, sweetness, hops, and funky yeast notes.  My only complaint is that the sour flash initially is a bit strong but soon mellows to a showcase the other supporting notes.  I have never had anything from this brewery that was not good.

Pours a dark caramel color with a massive creamy head that has bits of dark spots in it. Nose is caramelized, slightly sour, and a bit funky. Taste is sweet and sugary, like dehydrated pineapple rings with a little bit of caramel drizzle. Mouthfeel is a little watery and the finish is medium length and off sweet. Batch 286.

750ml bottle.
Opening and pouring this stuff was an absolute mess. Foam gushed everywhere the second the cap came off. Trying to get more than a couple ounces worth into a glass was a chore. I like a good foam on top of my beer, but this is beyond overkill. When it finally did settle into liquid form, it had a nice cloudy pale amber hue. Aroma is spicy, yeasty, earthy, grassy hops and grains. Flavor follows suit, as if one were drinking a liquid meadow minus the dirt and rocks. Hops are moderately bitter, while malt sweetness plays a background role only, just there to keep things under control. Full and creamy palate once the carbonation settles down. IMO this is one of Jolly Pumpkins weaker efforts, but its still pretty good.

750ml bottle courtesy of I believe JCB  thanks J!  This one was a slow gusher.  Pours a cloudy medium amber with a big 4 finger bubbly off-white head that lasts and some floaters.  The nose is unripe fruit and light malt vinegar.  The taste is coriander, unripe fruit, funky yeast and lemon peel with a dry earthy finish.  Medium extremely prickly mouthfeel.  Very good  thanks again J!

(Bottle) Pours amber with a large creamy off-white head. The aroma is spicy and bretty up front with notes of coriander, white pepper, horse blanket and barnyard. Fruity tones of lemons, apricots, apples, pears and pineapples. Light noble hops alongside a stable malt backbone. Subtle and fancy dryish oak. Undertones of leather and earth. The flavour is light sweet, light bitter and light to medium acidic. Good balance between the brett, malt, spices, wood and noble hops. Tones of lemon, pears, apples, coriander, white pepper, barnyard, basement and dryish oak. The mouthfeel is a bit tart yet soft with a medium, light champagne-like carbonation. The finish is light tart, light spicy and mild citric. Near medium bodied. Fantastic and well balanced.

Pours a slightly amber orange with thick, creamy white head, lots of lacing and stayed around for entire drink.  Aroma of a nice fruity perfume, tart fruits, spice, coriander, and grapefruit.  Flavor matches well and is very enjoyable.  Finishes slightly bitter.  Its not a pucker sour, but it has a lot of flavors to it.

Very hazy dark orange body; creamy frothy khaki head. Strongly aromatic - apple sauce, cinnamon, yeast and funk; spiced. Unique flavor - funk, yeast, coriander, lime, mint; herbaceous, bitter finish. Very yeasty, full bodied for a lighter beer. To summarize, very good.

Heres another tasty beverage from Jolly Pumpkin.  I shared a bottle of this with BeerBaron617.  It poured a nice amber color with lots of bubbles :)  It had a nice fluffy off white head.  Aroma, of course, was oaky, and had a bit of a light spicy and hoppy note to it.  It almost smelled like apple cider.  It was really tart for a pale ale, even though its a "Belgian"...It was really really spicy.  Overall a pretty tasty beverage, but still has that interest that Jolly brings to the table.
Bottle. Hazy amber colour with small creamy white Mostly diminishing head. Fruity and yeasty aroma. Sweet spicy flavor.
Bottle. Amber coloured with a thin off white head. Aromas of balsamic vinegar, acetone, vanilla and yeast. Dry and fresh taste with notes of brett, orange fruit, hops and spice.

750ml bottle - $8.49 at Beverage SuperStore in Suwanee, Georgia. No listed batch number.

Appearance: Pours out a clearish, dark orange body with a huge, dense, foamy, white head.

Smell: Malts enveloped with acrid notes of musty wild yeasts, butyric acid, juiced apples, mangled pineapples, damp oak wood, earthy spices.

Taste: Toasted, honeyish malts instantly disappear behind the strongly phenolic Brett character. Pristine pineapple juice blended with spoiled apple juice. The doses of Grains of Paradise and coriander are quite spicy and particularly pungent, giving the tongue a bit of enduring ginger-like heat. Touch of oak. Surprisingly bitter as well. Particularly dry finish with a lingering taste of the added spices.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium-high carbonation.

Drinkability: As always, its another weird, wild ride from Jolly Pumpkin. The spices can be a bit overly brash at times. While not the most captivating of the Jolly Pumpkin lineup, its certainly solid and worth a try.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2009 Bottle shared thanks to 502flavors.  Poured into snifter.  Poured a medium honey color with some carbonation coming up from the bottom and seriously aggressive off-white head that laced pretty well too.  The aroma is of unripe macintosh/machoon apples (half red/half green) and a mite vinegary.  The taste is spicier, not as tart and very refreshing.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2009 Bottle Batch 267/268.  Pours a glowing clear but darker burnt orange with a tall brett inspired airy foamy white towering head that eventually fades into a very fine head with nice lacing.  Aroma of brett, lovely oak, coriander, subtly sweet and sour.  First taste is strong brett but that quickly is integrated with the fantastic oak and well rounded spices.  A very round flavor, the oak, brett, maltines and spices really meld nicely while still being tantalizingly delicious, just fairly sour and sweet, touch creamy.  Nice long brett and oak aftertaste with just a touch of tart sourness.    Full mouthful, medium/light bodied, typical fizzy but soft brett dictated carbonation, uniform, dries the mouth out in the finish.
Clody golden with a tiny white head. Sweet and fruity aroma with discrete yeasty and citric notes. Flavour likewise. Finished sweet.

Greast musty smell with hints of spice, floral, just a lot going on here. Taste is Brett-like funk, hay, and the advertised herbs (very subdued and blended, I thought) and finishes nice and hoppy, a little tart. Impressive brew.

750ml bottle poured into a Trappist glass.  Ive wanted to try this beer for years.  I bought quite a few JP beers all together and saved this one for last.  To be honest, based on the other samples, I dont like their product as a whole.  Here goes with the final one...  Luciernaga pours orange-colored with a large fluffy head that lingers nicely.  The aroma has the vinegar cast that Ive come to associate with the brewery.  Theres also mild hops, coriander and faint bubble gum.  Like nearly all of their other beers this one is quite tart but not offensively so.  The tartness does drown out the flavors but the coriander shows through.  Im not impressed.

Bottle, rectangular label, bottle shape as pictured. Aroma of JP funk, diverse citrus notes (funky, tart, juicy, bitter orange, sweet orange, lemon, all sorts of stuff), floral hops, a lot more going on than in some other (newer?) JP beers Ive had of late that are just pure funk. Flavor has an unusually nice interplay between funky notes and bitter, hoppy notes as well as lightly bready malt. All in all pretty good, hard to find an area to criticize, though admittedly I dont think Id return to this.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy deep orange with a huge, thick frothy off-white head.  Aroma of sweet fruits, lemon, citrus, bitter hops, and sweet tart candies.  Flavor is sour/yogurty at first with a dry, malty, slightly bitter finish.  Palate is thin, sort of watery.  This is alright, certainly easy to drink but underwhelming.
8/4/8/3/14 (3.7/5)

750 ml bottle from Binnys (Orland Park, IL). Im excited to try this! Pours a very hazy fiery amber, orange and gold with amber, big billowy almost tannish white head. Laces very well. Very aromatic, pushing some heavy fruit esters: banana, pear, and some apple with good spicing, clove and grains of paradise, belgian yeast spice, vanilla and very light cinnamon. A bit of a wet grass, funk, but fruit kinda dominates. Initial is completely different: some bretty sourness and tartness come forward, light funk moving into a bit of barnyard and cheesiness. Light bodied, delicate without flavors necessarily dominating the beer over others. Strikes a nice balance, with the fruit taking in the backend of the palate with pear, apple, and light banana. Sticks to the palate, the funk and light tartness win me over as I sip this, relaxing the holiday weekend away. The spice is there, but gives way to fruit and funks delicate, flavorful, special balance. Cheers to this!

This is my first Jolly Pumpkin.  The beer starts off with a sour smell.  Reminds me of Rodenbach Grand Cru fresh in Belgium.  Huge amount of fluffy head.  The beers sour doesnt come through on the taste.  The body of the beer on the first sip doesnt linger. It is an easy drinking soured beer.

ultra dry musty nose. plenty of yeast on hand for aromas and also the carb that could have blown the cap through a brick wall and has my tulip filled with a cotton candy head. aroma evolves to the sweet yet dirty lemon flavor my brain has come to associate with wild yeasts. unbelievable and unmistakable stank of dirty straw and livestock. head has begun to recede but only around the edges, leaving a pimple like circle in its midst begging to be shattered of its pus: pure bready reeking organisms. before it has time to complete its recession into the depths of brew that lurk below, i perform my best rusty cunnilingus on the pimple, tempted to spell the ABCs and enjoying the musty murky flavors, not unlike a real vagina. i can wait no longer, tipping my glass nearly vertical so that the liquid breaks its foam barrier i am greeted with more leathery goodness and a strong malt background.  it ebbs and flows, the waves interspersed with more and more of the wonderful vitamin A laden yeast. more then a good beer, this is genius.  the low ABV prevents me from moving this nearly to the top of my list.

Thanks ogglethorp.  Clear amber pour, large, rocky, free-standing beige head.  Aroma has the Jolly Pumpkin house yeast funk and some cellar mustiness.  Flavor is principally yeasty, nice molasses theme in the malt backbone.  The finish is a bit off-rubbery. Palate is dry with an apple-peel astringency to it, very nice.
Sampled at DLD color was amber to orange with aromas of sour fruits and spice taste was sour fruits (like something went wrong not my style)spice and hops

2006 750ml bottle with the old style oval label. Hazy orange/amber with a rocky off white head. Earthy dry aromas of JP funk, cheese, dry hay, wood, with some caramel. Light body with a frothy mouthfeel.  Dust bowl dry flavors of toasted wood hay aged cheese and  pale malts. Gawddamn this shit is awesome !

text: Bottle at VV tasting, Odense. Pours cloudy amber/orange with a large fully lasting white head. Nose is fruity orange and hops. Dry and crisp taste with lots of brett , yeast and oak notes. Smooth and medium bodied. Ends super dry. Funky & Fresh!
Pours/gushes a golden brown with a huge head. Yeasty spicy aroma. Sweet fruit nose as well. Flavor is funky tart fruits and spice. Very dry in the finish.
Nice gold-yellow pour with white head.  Aroma of yeast, fruit, and spice. Flavor is like the aroma, but with some sourness and a dry aftertaste and mouthfeel.

Bottle from beermerchants.
HAzy gold/amber. Rocky, collapsing head.
Vinous. A spur, oxidized edge, probably due to the barrel aging. Soapy coriander and other spices. Pleasant, but challenging beer

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2010 batch 130/131 shared by psprings...


orange golden/brownish color with a spongy dense white head. 

mild jp stink mixes with bready yeast, earthy coriander, peppery spice, tart fruit similar to raisins and a distinct cheesy lactose smell. 

the flavor is very similar... add in a slightly tart, almost sour dry finish and it works. 

medium body with foamy carbonation that, when swirled out, makes it seem a bit flat and watery. dryness keeps me drinking it...7/4/7/3/16/3.7

bottle at daks by way of footy.

hazy apple juice color with a small off white head.

the aroma and flavor are apple juice, cement/minerals/jp funkiness, lots of citrus and herbaceous-ness.

the palate is super dry, dusty and really crisp. 7/4/7/4/16/3.8

Bottle.  Golden brown with a dense foam.  Aromas are citrus and yeast with spices.  Some light woodiness.  Quite Duvel-like.  Flavours are bitter lemon with lots of yeast.  Dry and hoppy on the finish.  Crisp and clean.
This one didnt have some of the odd funkyness some other JPs have had. Arom of bread, yeast, spice, and some citrus fruit. Taste is belgian spices, earthyness and some fruit.
Bottle.  Golden beer with a strong head.  The aroma is lightly sour and spiced, and the flvaour is sour, vinous and spiced.  Overall an average Belgian style beer.

Sampled at hellbillys hellraiser 3 gathering.  Yet another bottle courtesy of psprings!  Pours a golden orange color with a big foamy head.  Flavor and aroma of apples, yeast, wood, spice and a touch of funk.  A bit sour and very dry.  Nice.  Thanks Paul!

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph.
Pours hazy orange with a giant, frothy, off-white head. Aroma has caramel, lots of brett, wood, oranges, green apples and a touch of strawberries. Light tartness. High carbonation, good dryness, but perhaps a tad watery. Flavour is dry, brett, some funkiness, wood and subdued vanilla and melons. Elegant and extremely drinkable.

750 mL bottle from Bruisin Ales in Asheville, NC. Pours a clear copper color with a large head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of caramel, tart fruits including melon and strawberry. Taste is very dry with leafy vegetal notes, citrus and earthy notes. Full bodied.
Pours and orange color with some haziness.  Aroma and flavors are both funky brett, lemons, apples and a little spice.  Always a great beer.
Crushed with Jakebra at Falling Rock.  Nice spicy nose.  Coriander (first time Ive said that), light fruits, some funk.  Flavor is badass, funky and delicious.  One of the best JPs Ive had.

Hazy orange-amber colour.  Looks dull at a distance but held up to light it shimmers.  Rocky, thick head.  The aroma melds a distinct brettanomyces note with lively fruits such as mango, lemon and calamansi. Theres a subtle spice underpinning, along with light toasty malts.  The body has suprising alcohol firmness for a 6.5% beer.  Nice spritziness, too, and a juicy acidity.  The flavour leans towards herbal bitterness with just a hint of citrus.  The malts remain understated, despite providing light toast and substantial heft to the body.  The finish is very dry, highlighting a variety of characteristics including brettanomyces, dusty yeast, abundant herbal hop and just a kiss of acidity.  Strong wood notes are present throughout this beer but at no point do I find them dominant.  Complex, fantastic.
Botella. Deep golden colour. Fruity spiced sweet aroma. Good mouthfeel. Sweet and fruity spiced flavour with some yeast and a pleasant bitterness. Nice!

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2011 Bottle. Pours a darker orange brown with small head. Tart aroma. Some coriander, orange, and fruit in the taste. Smooth and balanced beer. RERATE. sampled at the pour house in westmont NJ. Pours a dark, hazy amber body with smooth carbonated white head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is the standard jolly pumpkin tart. Mouthfeel is incredibly smooth, with light notes of tart. Im lowering my initial 4.4 rating of this Guy just because its a bit tame. Absolutely nothing at fault though - a solid, deliciously brewed Belgian ale.
750 ml bottle. The first word that is on mind is apple. Aroma has little hops and more apples. So does the flavor. Amber colour with white head. Quite interesting beer.

22 fl oz bottle. Pours hazy orange with a huge, white, rocky and slowly collapsing dense head. Aroma is dry brett with a mild caramel note and a subdued fruity hops accent. Smooth hoppy, mild brett and orange fruity flavoured - delicate coriander spice notes. Nice mild caramel malty base with a light and delicate sweetness. Medium dry, orange fruity and light hops bitterness into a smooth and nicely balanced finish.
Amber in color and cloudy with a thick creamy head. Aroma is of apples, light hops and a little grass. Flavor is moderately hoppy with some grain and apples.
Orange with white head.  Pepper, apply, yeast, wood.  A little sour.  Aftertaste is tart and dry.  Not my favorite, but a very complex and interesting beer.

750 ml bottle via trade batch 296/297 according to the sticker on back. Ok now Im not sure if I had gotten a semi-infected bottle but i read about 6 pages of reviews and no mention of bad bottles anywhere. Initial pour was a crisp clear burnt orange-amber with lots of rising carbonatin and a super huge foamy white head. End of the bottle was a very hazy burnt orange-amber with an average size creamy white head. Now the aroma is what made me think this one might have been on the off side because that classic sour lemon, wet wood, funky aroma was the only scents coming through. Palate was my next clue with a thin body and super strong carbonation that seemed to foam up even more upon hitting your mouth. My third and final clue was the only flavor that was detectable was some sour ass funk. Now maybe Im still not a brett/sour fan but this one by no means lived up the hype of a 3.81 beer with close to 500 ratings (at the time I rated it anyway).
Bottle at CSAs - Thanks. Clear yellow - white head. Brett, peppery, fruity, wood, oak, coriander, light wine feeling, apples, light yeasty, light sourness - brett sourness, dry finish. NICE.

750ml bottle thanks to dchmela. Pours a glowing golden orange with a fluffy off-white head that has great retention and very good lacing. Aroma of wood, coriander, red wine, sweet caramel and slight diacetyl note. Taste is dry with a bit of funk and light tartness. Some caramelized pop-corn, wood and an interesting herbal note. Lively bubbles and a bone dry mouthfeel.

750ml bottle (batch 296/297) served in a Duvel tulip. Pours light amber with a massive fluffy head, effervescent carbonation. Lots of sour apple on the nose as well as some wood and funk. Very dry throughout with light spiciness, has notes of leather, wood, funk, apple, bread. Finishes dry with a light tartness. The head lasts forever and ever and leaves some impressive lacing. Very interesting.

0.75 l bottle at Konttori, Tampere. Hazy copper to amber color with creamy head. Sour horsey aroma with raspberry, strawberry and oak. Dry, sour and horsey flavor with strawberry and some spicy phenols. Slightly tannic yet silky mouthfeel.

750 ml bottle. Finland. AW09. Batch 296/297. Orange colour.
Fruity (mainly apple) aroma. Flavour is also fruity, apple, sour but still fresh. Some yeast.

(Bottle -- thank you sayravai for sharing me a rating dosage -- at Pikkulintu. Helsinki, on 2009-01-23) Dark orange. Cloudy. Small white head. Sour and fruity nose. Full bodied and dry palate with little carbonation. Sourness, fruitiness, bitterness and bit of grapefruit in taste. Bitterness and sourness in aftertaste.

(Bottled) Clear amber with almost no head. Sourish and acidic aroma with some caramely maltiness. Dry and sourish-malty flavor with some caramely maltiness. Medium-bodied, slicky palate with low, soft carbonation. Pleasant, Orval-like, dry and tart brew.

Orange colored with cloudy appearance. Sour aroma with some wooden-dry lemony and spicy note. Medium bodied, strong carbonation. Flavor is more lemony with same dryness and mild chocolate, aftertaste lasts with same drought.

Bottle 75 cl. Hazy amber color. Good display of lacework. Lovely notes of fruit, barnyard, hors blanket, rubber, earth, wood. Medium bodied, average carbonation, dry texture. Moderate sweet and sour flavor. Lingering fruity sour finish.

Complex, well rounded, lightly sour ale.  Light and spicy, with notes of coriander, clove, vanilla and some malt depth and complexity, slight toffee. A little musty, and flowery from hops.  Has that undescribeable "brett" flavor, often called barnyard. A definite farmhouse character to this one.

750ml bottle. Poured with half a glass of foam. Same as another user here in Orlando experienced the same week, the store may not have handled them well. Light copper color. Had a nice tart lemony aroma. Nice and dry with a spicy and slightly sour charactor. Very nice beer.

Bottle. Pours a clear orange-amber with a thick, foamy, off-white head. Sour aroma, of under-ripe fruits, yeast, and spices. Taste is sour and sweet, nicely fruity, with malt, yeast, and spices. Lingering fruity sourness. Tasty.

Belle bière blonde, voilée, mousse abond et durable.

Goût frais amer et suret.

Dark brown colour and unclear. Has an off-white head. Aroma is acid, sulfur, candis. Flavor is heavy acidic, light sweet. Palate is sharp, acid, dry, somehow soft too. Like a lambic.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2009 Re-rate 8/29/09.  No gusher this time.  Pours a golden-amber color with a thick khacki head.  The aroma is coriander, bretty, spices, funk.  Spices and coriander flavors mix with light hops.  Very dry and a bit sour and tart in the finish.  A really good beer.  Slight bump.  Original rating:  This started over flowing as soon as I opened it up, out of control, took some effort to settle it down.  Amber colored, a lot of carbonation, huge foamy head that eventually settled to a nice level.  Fruity and yeasty, light with some spice, light bitterness and a tangy sour presence.  Good one, I enjoyed this beer.  These JP brews are a bit expensive though.

Pours an amberish color with a big, rocky head. Sour, spicey aroma with some licorice, some pepper, some coriander. The flavor is very tart with a lot of spice, lots of orange peel and pepper, a tad funkiness. Almost wish they’d tone down the spiciness, but, man, still an amazing brew.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2009 Poured a nice amber color with a very small white head. Aroma was mof sour apples, dampness, hops and some spices. Flavor is overwhelmed by the sour fruitiness and spices, hops are hiding in there just even to be known. Really interestiong brew and my first from jolly pumpkin, cant wait to try more.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2008 750 into wine glass really shaken up.  I had been looking forward to this one for a long time;  I had it with some empty collectible bottles and a De Dolle Extra Export Stout and De Dolle Special Reserva in a box to take home from school. Really good stuff, I need to get more and rate it with the proper mindset. Unfortunately the 2 De Dolles were casualties... RIP!
Bottle pours an orange body with a white head.  Spicy light traditional JP funkiness, light cherry and oak.   Coriander, pepper.  Good brew.

A golden amber hazy ale with a thick frothy white head. Apleasant pungeant aroma of herbs, field grass, orange, Jaegermeister,  and licorice.  In mouth, a rich pungeant malt, with light acidity, orange peels, and warming alcohol. Rich and interesting. Shared with Mike H., Aug. 2008.

Pours hazy dark golden color with big off white head. Aromas of hops and  corriander. Similar flavors with some spiciness. Light to medium body with effervescent carbonation and a slightly dry finish.

batch 296/297...bottle sort of exploded on me, but that lead to a murky amber pour with a rock solid white head.  aroma is tart and mildly horsey.  wonderful tart flavor with a nice hop background.  great bottle to share after a long day...

hazy and golden with nice thick white head.  medium carbonation.  a bitter and somewhat floral nose.  flavor of belgian yeast with some hop bitterness, finishes with some citrus flavors from the grains of paradise with a bone dry finish and maybe some spiciness.  subtlety is always the key to holly pumpkin brews and this is no different.  i am not as keen on the grains of paradise, but a well crafted and unique brew

Brown bottle, 1 pint 9.4 ounces, batch 296/297, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, savoured on November 8 2008; eye: copper, hazy, light effervescence, voluminous tan head made up of average size bubbles and that falls to look like melting ice cream, a bit of lacing; nose: woody, light spices, blue cheese, yeast, horse, malt, light sourness; mouth: horse, woody, yeast, soft pepper, light grapefruit, rather dry finale in yeast with pepper, lightly sour, foamy texture, medium-full body, average carbonation; overall: quite likable

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 1 pinte 9,4 onces, lot 296/297, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, savourée le 8 novembre 2008; il : cuivrée, voilée, légère effervescence, mousse fauve abondante formée de bulles moyennes et qui tombe pour se transformer en de la crème glacée fondue, un peu de dentelle; nez : boisé, léger épices, fromage bleu, levure, cheval, malt, légère aigreur; bouche :cheval, boisé, levure, poivre doux, léger pamplemousse, finale plutôt sèche en levure avec du poivre, légèrement aigre, texture mousseuse, corps moyen-corsé, carbonatation moyenne; en résumé : bien aimé

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2011 10/29/08. Bottle. 7/4/8/4/14 - 3.7Good white head, nice lacing. Moderately sour, green apple, grapefruit. Finish is pretty dry and bitter, mostly grapefruit. The malt character is mixed w/ some barnyard-decent but not very good. Coriander. This beer has some sweet fruitiness to it as well. 

750mL from Jubiliation. One of those uber slow gushers. This one had four separate escape attempts. I basically reiterate everything from my previous rating, minus the fruit, aint much of that. I like the balance a bit more than i did before. 7/4/8/4/15

Cloudy orange body with nice white head.  Spicy aroma with a little bit of funk and a little bit of funk.  The flavor is tangy orange peel and some pepper.  Finishes rather dry and is very similar to Orval, but to a lesser degree.  Pretty tasty beer.

Bottle, courtesy of Mcbackus. Pours a hazy amber/orange color with a thick, foamy white head. Gobs of white lacing coated the glass. Nose was fruity and sour. Medium bodied palate with a fair amount of carbonation. Flavor starts out really sour, like vinegar, but mellows out as the beer warms. Flavors of green apple, white grapes, orange peel, lemon, as well as many others I can,t put my finger on, are present. This is my fourth Jolly Pumpkin Ale and I must say, they are a complex. Loved it.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2009 Bottle from tytoanderso, thanks bro!  Poured a hazy golden-amber color with a thick, dense off-white head that left some good spotty lacing.  Light funky aroma with some cobweb and barnyard, as well as some moderate spices (coriander and grains of paradise as described),  some dry citrus fruit (orange peel, lemon), and a hint of floral hops.  Tart, funky entry with some barnyard and cobweb-like yeastiness right up front transition into moderate fruitiness (orange, tangerine, and apricot) with a bit of coriander spice that finishes with a moderately bitter hoppiness with some lingering yeasty flavors.  Moderate carbonation.  Smooth with a moderate bite on the palate.  More enjoyable than some of the other JP beers I have had.

GABF 08: Pretty clear golden color with a bubbly head.  Sour, funky nose of white wine, fermenting plums and nectarines and just a fresh zesty aura.  Tame fruity flavors with a somewhat grainy presence.  Not remarkably sour yet just so in a fruity type of way.

Here is another winner that Adrian came up with.  Label looks like the cover of a fantasy novel.  Aroma of apple and grapes.  Taste is sour with peppery hops.  This has a funky, earthy, homemade vibe - off the beaten track and worth a visit.  If you have snobby friends, you could impress them by breaking out a bottle of this - and I don’t mean that as an insult to the beer.

Pours a cloudy, dark orange.  Massive off-white head.  Sour smelling, sour tasting.  Really complex ale... sweet at first, then the spice hits.  Coriander, dandelion, bitter greens and hops to finish.  Fantastic!

Lovely orange coppery pour with tinted head.  Nice citrus and wood aroma.  Taste starts boldly with a big blast of citrus, grass, and funk.  The finish is however austere -- too dry for my likes -- with citrus (grapefruit) musty socks and a touch of phenol. Very reminiscent of Orval, which I love.  Maybe I am being too harsh in trying to make this comparison, as it is just not there. Needs more body.  Still, a good try. Caged bottle.

750ml bottle (didn’t write down the batch number) from WLV.... medium yellow orange pourwith a substantial slightly off-white head..... aroma of lightly spiced tart citrus fruit.  a little musty..... flavors of citrus (lemons mostly with some orange) paired well with light spices.  not overly tart but had enough to quench the craving. earthy and dry finish.  good carbonation and semi-lively mouthfeel....pretty darn close to a 4 for me

750ml bottle.  Pours a gusher!  Look out!  Color is orange with a huge, fluffy white head.  Nose is of yeast, spices and funk.  Taste is of apple, spices, herbs and grass. Mouthfeel is medium-to-thin, tart and dry with super carbonation.  Very drinkable.  polished this one off myself.

Off amber couldy look with an everlasting thick foamy beige colored head.  Good lacing.  Smell is spices, cooriandor, tartness, and fruit.  Taste is a touch of bitterness, some spices, and tartness.  Good beer.

Capped 750. I’m not sure of the vintage, but I know I have been cellaring this for about 2 years. I had reason to celebrate a little tonight, so I figured why not break this baby out? I was not disappointed... lightly hazed orange amber with a massive off white head that descended rockily. Thick, sticky lace. Orange scents, light tropical fruit and just a bit of barnyardy. Traces of dust and cinnamon. Rather light bodied, orange zest and spicy coriander, rather dry and herbal. Some woodiness emerges as it warms and breathes, some white peppery notes. Dry, mildly bitter herbal finish. Thanks, JP - and here’s to me and my new position!

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2012 After further reviews and batches, I am not quite as ecstatic about this. It is still excellent, but a little less flavorful and overly spritzy. It also lacks the restraint of the similar Orval. Still... shimmering amber with a long-lasting white head, lacing. The brain registers minor citrus on the nose, then some caramel and malt tucked in the back. Yeast is throughout. Then the beer shifts gears and slams it out of the park with mother nature funk, like an earthy, clay sulfur/egg/barnyard thing. Belts are totally fastened now.The flavor: sweet orange, lemon, apple, and spice cruising down a highway of pepper-dusted wood, yeast, alcohol, and minor hop there as well. Medium-bodied and strongly carbonated.

Much thanks to July Santa for this bottle! (Shared with KAggie97) Bright orange pour with kick ass had. Nose is typical JP...spices, fruit, tartness, barnyard....yum. Flavor is sour with good acidity. Lemons, apples and wood notes as well.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2012 Bottle 8/22/08

Opens with a puff and then gushes for a good 15 minutes. Nice rich amber orange, massive textured head forming clumps as it subsides. Tart, tannic aroma, spice, apple, plenty of fruit --- these come through in the flavor, definitely some sour, lots of oak, quite strongly herbal with the grains of paradise and coriander mixing up nicely with the general flavor profile. Pretty dry, lemon juice, some hops on the close. Very different, very enjoyable! 

Tap at JP in Ann Arbor 7/16/12
Straw and lemon, JP funk. I spent more time enjoying and less time analyzing, but heck of a nice beer and the 4.0 stands.

Bottle shared with Zinister.  Thanks!Nice, deep cheddar orange brew with an aroma of spicy, sweet wood- mostly cedar, but perhaps a bit of pine as well.  .  Flavor is oak-tinged seltzer water in a mixture of zesty lemon lime.  Mouthfeel reminds me of a Pilsner with an attitude.  Refreshing brew.  Wouldn’t mind more of this.
