text: Bottle from John’s Market Place in Portland, OR--Poured a shiny yet hazy copper-amber body with a thick rough off-white head.  Nose of rich caramel and funk.  Spiciness coupled with fruit notes such as apples, pears, and flower peddles.  Subtle booziness lingered. Carried on with a bright prickly carbonic tongue presence and finished sour, bitter, sweet, and dry.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2009 Bomber at Jerrys. Cloudy caramel-amber with big, foamy beige head / Big, aromatic nose of fruit and caramel / Light bodied, tart and crisp, with delicate carbonation, a silky, balanced body, and a long finish / Flavors of green apple, lemon, pear, caramel, chrysanthemum, oak, coriander, and lots of earthy funk / Lacking a little of the complexity (maybe?) of other JP offerings, but still spectacular.

Pours a dark golden cloudy hue.  Head is big and white, with lots of lacing.  Nose of funk, tart fruit, oak.  Taste is similar with apple, spice, hops, and plenty of sourness.  Some mild yeast as well.  Mouth is carbonated and relatively light.  Finish is bitter, sour, and sweet.

750Ml Bottle-Cloudy golden color w/a huge foamy head. Strong alcohol aroma. Funky, woodsy flavor of spiced apples, lemon, colander, orange peel, & oak. Mouthfeel is very thin & reminds me of a cheap scotch. Thought this one was just to far out there & out of balance to enjoy. Long, burnt liquor finish.
Poured a cloudy ruddy brown. The nose and flavor are tart and funk dominated with some spice. Tart, lasting finish.

On tap at the MBG Summer Fest 08’.  Poured a cloudy dark golden color.  Nice must and funk on the nose, with a hint of spice.  First thing that hit me about the flavor was that this was a solid and classic beer.  Just plain tasty.  Tiny bit of funk, must, herbal hops, light spice, with a nice dry finish.  This won’t blow your socks off, but this one just struck me right.

Next from Jolly Pumpkin is the Luciernaga.  The pour gives a thick tan and tangerine head that shows no sign of fizzling down after a sizeable wait.  The beer itself is an eclipsed orange and brown with a blizzard of bubbles.  While the head never really dissolves, it slowly breaks down into a fascinating block of bubbly ruins and castle turrets.  The aroma is rich and soft, though the aromas themselves are from sharper things - tobacco, leather, fried food, scotch, butter, dandelions, pepper, Jalapenos and a little lemon.  Rich, but very desert and Southern hemisphere, without the creams and sweets I typically enioy.  The taste features these same kind of "musty" flavors", like shoe leather, tobacco, peppers and scotch again, and the acquired taste of olive.  I like it, but it’s odd.  A bit old mannish in its appeal, but for that very same reason, distinctive and sophisticated.

gusher. pours dark amber brown with sticky frothy head.  has that jolly pumpkin profile - lightly tart, musty and dry. moderate bitter hop. some light spice on exhale if you’re looking for it. the flavors are subtle all around, which would make it a nice sessionable belgian if it didn’t cost so much.   an excellent beer, no doubt, but for the money i think i prefer bam, roja and golden a bit more.

Tasted 6/22/08.  750ml bottle.  Hazy with a golden amber hue.  Two fingers of bone white head.  Woody, tart raspberry aromas.  Green apples and spices.  Rather medium bodied with a tart palate.  Big effervescence.  Citrus notes.  Slightly burnt malt character.  Muted hops.  Nice palate switch between the tart and sweet.  Mildly sour with a higher drinkability.

Hazy orange with a massive white head.  Aroma is wheat, citrus, hay, spice, tied together with a nice overarching sour ale quality. Taste is pretty similar, with the spice/sourness becoming the most prominent flavors. Very smooth, yet the finish is clean and dry. Very nice beer.

Bottle. Pours a hazy orange, nice fluffy white head. Aroma is a little funky and citrusy. Flavor is a little sour and very Wit-like, almost like an Imperial Wit (if there were one). Orange, lemon and spice dominate the flavor profile. dry and bitter on the finish. Ill buy this one again.

Bottled, thanks Crosling!  Clear amber, lively head. Barnyardy and yeasty up front. Medium sweet and freshly hoppy with vital crisp mouthfeel and medium body. Notes of butter, herbs and lemon. Superbly complex and beautifully balanced. Herbal bitter finish.

Decided to continue my Jolly Pumpkin kick as of recent, so picked this one up for a whirl.  Pours golden with one of the most obscene heads Ive ever seen...something was definitely going on inside this bottle to create this puppy!  Leaves ridiculous levels of lacing as it slowly settles.  Aroma is spicy and citrusy with a decent dose of hops mixed in.  Flavor is a real roller coaster...very tart and funky up front, then smooths out for a bit before the hops emerge late and the finish is very bitter and dry.  Catch a lot of spice in the flavor (nutmeg was prevalent), and theres a heavy grassy note throughout.  Carbonation level was too high to have a real good drinkability level.  I didnt like the mix of the funk and the bitterness too much...this was a very interesting beer, but probably my least favorite JP offering to date...

As Ive read about many of JPs beers, my bottle was a spewer which prompted a premature tasting of copious amounts of foam.  Beautiful golden color with an abundant fluffy white head.  Aroma of spices, citrus and grassy summer fields.  Orange peel dominated the spices in the flavor, however, especially compared to others Grand Cru-style beers Ive sampled.  The dryness and texture of this beer was incredibly champagne-like.  Its a great summer beer, but too cost-prohibitive for frequent thirst slaking.

5-4-08 bottle 
Pours a medium yellow orange color.  Smell is watermelon and tart.  Super sour smell but flavor is a hint weak in comparison.  Nice overall, just a hint milder than I figured it would be.

5/31/2008:  Luciernaga (The Firefly) pours a hazy caramel color with a large, dense and creamy beige-colored head.  There is a generous amount of carbonation that helps sustain the rocky head and puffy lacing from the pour to the last drop.  The aroma contains citrus (orange and lemon) and delicate spice.  It is very inviting.  The flavor is malty and fruity (hint of bubblegum too) at first and then the spiciness (nutmeg and corriander) and some dryness hits in the mid-palate along with a touch of tartness.  The finish is smooth and slightly bitter and has some floral hoppiness followed by a touch of grassy citrus (like faint lemongrass or something).  This beer is really well-balanced and quite refreshing.  It is dry, yet efferevescent on the palate with medium body and a smooth mouthfeel.  This beer is quite complex and very enjoyable!
750 ml bottle (6.5% alc/vol) with oval label and a dark green cap from Belmont Party Supply in Dayton, Ohio.  Rating #414 for this beer...

Poured an effervescent golden with a large fizzy/fluffy white head.  Pleasant aroma of grassy hops, lemony citrus, a bit of spiciness and a touch of alcohol.  Flavor follows pretty closely.  Bitter grassy hops with notes of ginger and other spices balance with a refreshing lemony tartness, leading to a spicy dry finish.  Body is light and fluffy.  Served cool, this beer was as refreshing as it was surprisingly complex.  This could pass as an awesome summertime beer for true beer aficionados.  This is also the first Jolly Pumpkin beer that Ive really enjoyed.
turbid, sour taste and smell.  im not really a fan of this style so i have to admit that im a bit biased and my ratings will prolley reflect that

Big bottle. Golden hazy with fluffy cloudy head, that never went away. Spice, coriander, abit on the vinegar side and malt aromas. Spicy chewy taste at first, Dry body with some lingering carbonation. Bitter aftertaste. This was a nice clean beer.
Hazy orange in color with a nice fluffy head. Great spice in the nose. Wonderful effervesence. Good, mild spices- perfect combo. Very well balanced.

22 oz Bomber. Pours a nice hazy golden color with a huge foamy eggshell colored head that leaves thick rings of lacing around the glass. Aroma is filled with vinegar, lemon, spice, funk, grass, and magnum 44 sharpie marker. Taste is very interesting spices kick you right in the mouth at first then fade nicely into a lemony flavor with some light hoppy bitterness. Mouthfeel is very dry almost like a white wine, heavy carbonation reminds you quickly though that you are in fact drinking a beer, and a nice medium body. Overall I enjoyed this beer and would recommend it for a nice relaxing summer outing at the park.

22 oz. bottle on 5/15/08. Pours out a faintly hazy gold with a foamy, yet sturdy, white head that lasts to the bottom of the glass and leaves some spider web lace. Earthy aroma with hints of lemon and spice. Medium body, lively effervescence, and a very dry and somewhat acidic palate. Flavor is decidedly bitter right up front, the light maltiness lurking behind, and a tangy, spicy finish.
UPDATED: AUG 21, 2010 Aroma of citrus and flower hops.  Also a sour fruit note.  Hazy orange brew with a white head.  Flavor is sweet with sour and fruity yeast flavors.  Smooth and medium bodied.

Pours bright and cloudy orange.  Tart sour orange smell with light vinegar.  Taste is super mild, lightly funky and not really tart at all.  Faintly fruity, but rather dull and boring, in fact.  Fizzy mouthfeel and some mild bittering hops.  Not impressed...

22oz bomber from Redlight Redlight at Brents recommendation. Pours a huge towering white head and a cloudy burnt orange. Head sticks around for awhile leaving some nice lacing. Aroma is similar to a belgian wit but with sour funk and some citrus hops smells interesting. Some light sourness at the front of the palate giving way to a belgian yeastiness. Extremely dry finish with a light hoppiness. Good strong carbonation makes this extremely easy drinking. This reminds me quite a bit of an aged Orval but it doesnt have the same magic. Still very good with a pleasant lingering aftertaste that is not bitter at all but rather pleasantly spicy. Well done!

A great Belgian ale from a great brewer. Aroma of funk, yeast and lemon. Pour was a lovely murky light brown with a 3 finger off white head. Taste was great. Dry, yeast and spices. A nice amount of funk and a grassy lemony aftertaste. Very dry and delicious.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle.  When I opened the bottle, the head poured and poured out!  Pouring into the glass there was a  little beer and four inches of head which quickly dissipated into a thick cloud.  Under the cloud a nice amber.  Aroma was hoppy, flowery, and spices (nutmeg and clove).  Tasted of hops and spice, a bit of pince and some oakiness too.

Bottled sample via boutip. Hazy orange in cololur with moderate champagne-like carbonation. Aromas of funk Belgian yeast, coriander, light herbal hops, and a bit of wood. Theres a bit of light malt flavor in the mouth, along with more wood, funk, gentle hops, spice, and some lemony sourness.  Fairly dry with a light fruity finish. It hides its 6.5% AVB very well. Overall, this isnt a beer thats going to blow your mind, but its very gentle and well balanced.
[bottle] Poured straw gold with a massive fluffy white head that stuck around. Aroma was quite spicy with some barnyard funk and yeasty goodness. Flavor was tart, spicy, and finished dry. Good stuff.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2008 Orange, iced tea pour.  Huge, frothy off-white head with a lot of staying power.  Some cascading lace.  Nose is one-dimensional but inviting aroma of yeast and sour citrus, mainly a tangerine-orange montage.  More funky tangerine, lemon pith, a smidgen of pear, and a little spice.  Finishes dry and spicy with a lingering orangey aftertaste. Hops are  semi noticeable but the fruity palate takes the forefront.  Very tart and effervescent.  Decent.
A cloudy dark gold (slight amber) pour with very large thick head.  Funk, sweetness that is similar to honey, orange, fruit, berry flavors, and grassy herbal notes.  Also hints of spice and oak.

another gusher, but not as aggressively as others ive had from jp.  huge, dense, rocky off-white head that sticks around forever.  seriously.  its meringue instead of beer foam.  it went down about an inch every five minutes.  it took a while before i even noticed the deep and hazy honey-gold beer sitting beneath it.  the smell is sort of classic jolly pumpkin:  lots of funk stand out first, then it fades into an earthy, grassy note, with lemon zest in the background.  some vanilla and spice mingle with the honey malt to form a decent malt note.  taste is lighter on the funk, with a lot more spice, a lot more earthy and grassy hops, and a lot less citrus.  pretty bitter on the finish, seemingly the combined result of the hops and the spicy astringency.  quite dry, as expected, with a lot of carbonation for an incredibly creamy mouthfeel.  not as slaking as id hoped.  id drink it again, but the maracaibo especial still tops this, for my tastes.

Hmm, pours medium amber with a goos sized head. Aroma is like a very strong witte with corriander and orange. Mouthfeel is nice with lively carbonation, amybe a bit thin, but not watery.  Flavor is where they liost me.  There is a nice yesty characteristic mixed with spice and a bit of fruit, but all of that is overwhelmed by the grassy hops that dominate this beer.  Certainly not bad, but could use a bit more balance.

UPDATED: APR 9, 2008 750ml Bottle.  Nice coriander aroma with hints of spice.  Mouth is well carbonated like all other Jolly Pumps so far.  Taste is more spicy than the nose would suggest, oranges round out the flavor and shavings of the peels are noticable in the hazy bottle toped with a large fluffy head.  Finishes dry.

75oml.  Ive had this beer a few times, once before JPs QA turned weaker, and a few times after.  Every time after has been fairly low carbonated and dissappointing...but I still remember that one time I had the original or one of the original batches...and that blew me away.  Ill rate that taste.

Very heady beer regardless of how gently I poured it. This is a thick and cloudy deep-gold beer that smells spicey and vaguely fruity. Very full in the mouth, a bit high on the carbonation level for my taste. The flavors in the beer hit my tongue in various stages, the spice hit me first followed shortly after by the bitterness of the hops. The grain and spice dominate the mouth primarily and the taste is all around well balanced, leaving a satisfying cacophony of flavor in your mouth for a bit after.

bottle

To be honest, I just wasnt all that thrilled with this beer.  It has many of the same qualities as a lot of other JP beers, but falls short in the flavor.  Very dry finish.  Good Brett character, but not too much else.  Sourness level is nice, but a bit thin.  Id much prefer Oro de Calabaza, or even La Roja to this.  Slightly overcarbonated as well.

750mL of gushy goodness, filled two 16oz glasses with foam and the bottles was still erupting.  Nice 16 part pour into a Raftman tulip, big fluffy foam, decent retention.  The funk has taken control of this bad motha fudga, big brett nose, huge lacto flavor, any hint of what they actually made this from is lost under the Bootsy Collins sized funk.  I like the funk and all, but dear sweet jeebus, this might as well be a spice lambic.
A delicious Belgian ale that is well balanced. Bottle. Cloudy amber with huge white head. Tons of carbonation. Lots of spice, yeast and doughy malts with a touch of funkiness. A well made beer.

750 mL bottle via Lubiere, shared with Ben, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. MR 15/08
App.:  Cloudy medium-amber, decent off white foam with generous lacing.
  
Aroma:  FUNKY, sour, green bitter herbs, loads of lemon and coriander, yeast, subtle hints of caramel, barnyard, piss, rubber, white pepper.
  
Palate:  Medium body and moderate effervescence with a touch of astringency.
  
Flav.:  Lots of organic acids, coriander, white pepper, those green bitter herbs, some barnyard funk a hint of softer, sweet flavours, some light fruitiness (mainly pome fruits and a touch of dark dried fruits); quite tart and very bitter. 

A very Lambic-like Belgian ale.  Complex and perplexing.

Pours a gorgeous, hazy, glowing medium gold.  A huge, foamy, off-white head is incredibly well retained, leaving diverse, organic splotches of lacing behind.  The aroma shows dry, funky Belgian yeast throughout.  Notes of pale golden malts, orange peel, lemon peel, fresh flowers, and dry, herbal hops work together in perfect harmony.  In addition to the aforementioned elements, the flavor features a moderate use of coriander, a component that is prone to overuse is many a pale Belgian.  The spicy, floral hop character is perfect here, working wonderfully with the dryness that the Brett imparts.  Medium bodied, with a bone dry palate, this is exactly what I look for in a session brew.  This would pair wonderfully with a myriad of culinary treats.  Awesome brew.  My favorite Jolly Pumpkin, and something I will be stockpiling from here on out.

July 2007 - Light amber to orange color, small head, very little lacing.  Funky lambic horseblanket like aroma.  Flavor was a vast amalgamation of styles, horseblanket, sour vinegar, grapefruit hops, sweet fruit and a touch of caramel.  Dry mouthfeel, light on the tongue.  Definitely something different.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2009 THIS BEER KICKS ASS. Brett is my best friend. Nose is full-on Brett so are the flavors. So complex, so dry, so inviting, and so gorgeous with its rich, rocky foam. Thank you very much mgumby for sharing this outstanding beauty.Pours cloudy dark amber-gold with outstanding thick and foamy head. Wafting aromas of Brett and orange rind and minty herbs. Smooth but lively carbonation. Strong herbal character with an exquisite Brett character and a lingering hoppy finish. Didnt stun me as much as when I had it the first time but still in love.

The head was what first caught our attention -- chunky and lively. A bit caught on the lip of th bottle, causing Beershine to remark, "Yes, it is erotic, and its bothering me." Mike (Gumby) says he is going to quote that comment too. Actually, I was entranced by the label as soon as Mike pulled it out. 

Lets not forget th flavor: so smooth and sophisticated and, well, downright magical -- as the label art suggests.

750ml bottle.  My 2nd beer from Jolly Pumpkin, not sure yet if Im into their style.  It seems like they need a new style made up thats just for them.  Mostly clear golden with an orange glow.  Enormous off white that left some thick lacing.  Not sure how to describe the nose.....spicy........sour.........fruity?  Flavor was sour with some notes of oak and spice.

Thanks to Drew for this one.  Pours gold with a thick effervescent beige head.  The aroma has a cinnamon spice character to it along with the citrusy sour funk.  The flavor is also somewhat spicy with a dry bitter note in the middle finishing with a funky sourness.  The flavors all around are very subdued and seem to be hiding amidst a watered down body.  I expected more.

Had at one of the Cellars weekly beer tastings.  I have yet to have a bad beer from this brewery.  Copper orange pour with a fluffy two finger white head.  Aroma of sour citrus and spices (cloves? and coriander) with biscuit.  The flavor has a great tartness to it.  Citrus and light fruit with the spices again.  A great mixture of flavors and tartness.
Large bottle: Drank most of this myself.  Very good.  Pours amber with a huge head.  Aroma of hops and raisons.

750 pours, um, gusher - holy crap look out!  Do not panic, we are trained professionals!  Multiple glass pour, with lots of clingy merang like head and classic lace.  Appearance is slightly hazed copper amber.  The aroma is yeasty, clover field, spicy, coriander, bret, lemon, sour dough pancakes with syrup, and some leather shop.  The flavor is fruity, some lemon, tart, salt, wild honey sweetness wrapped in a funky shell laced with vanilla, some hops - lots of trippy symphonic complexity.  A lingering sourness that really gives it character.  The palate is fizzy and cleansing, very refreshing despite the funkiness.   Wow, wild brew - I like.

Pours a cloudy orange amber with a frothy white head and nice lacing. Aroma is sweet fruit, dougy yeast and spicy coriander. Flavor has a nice bitterness to it as well as some tartness, oak and spice. Small to medium bodied. Sticky texture, short to medium spicy finish.

Another wonderful beer from Jolly Pumpkin. Im really starting to love these guys. Aromas of vinegar and cave, musty and pleasant. Extremely complex flavor. Kind of hard to disect. Floral and hoppy, sour and balanced. A great beer. Wish the bottle was a bit bigger because I really want some more of this one.

Deep golden-orange beer with a thick pillowy white head.  Very moussy and sticky lacing.  Aroma is fantastic... musky, purfumey aroma with rich bretty funk, a kiss of vanilla, citrus and some nice earthy hops.  Some apple/pear fruitiness with some apple-skin-like tannic character.  Spicy flavour, lightly peppery with a lovely pear ester character.  Some earthy/spicy hops, soft bitterness.  Creamy palate.  Leathery dryness with a lovely perfumy aroma.  Excellent balance and a fantastic beer.

The pour is very light orange with a little brown. The head is very thick, creamy, frothy, off white. The aroma is fruity, tart, acidic, hops, alcohol, yeast, and some spice. The flavor is spicy, citrusy, some fruit, tart, acidic, yeasty, and most of the qualities of the aroma. Very spicy. nicely carbonated palate.

The nose is both tart and spicy with scents of corriander, allspice, clove, tart clementine and lemon.  In the mouth it is very smooth and sexy with a silky finish.  Soft but deep in the midpalate with some dryness at the very end of the finish.

75 cl bottle. Orange color, pours an enormous frothy head. Strong aroma of citrus(lemon and grapefruit) and coreander, combined with other nondescript spices. Bitter, spicy flavor with grapefruit and coreander notes. Well made beer with a strong aroma, maybe a bit too spicy.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2008 The smell is something I just cant put a finger on. Is it cranberries, as Joris pointed out in his review? Or is it something else? Whatever the hell it is, its great. Even my girlfriend kept smelling it, and she doesnt drink beer. Super acidic brett in the nose, with backing fruity sweet malts. The taste is less in your face brett as the aroma, and more of a balanced, Orval kinda thing. And I like it. Sweet caramel and almost-plum malts sit beneath spicy, citrusy, floral hops, with a beautiful, barely acidic green apple finish. Now for my 2 complaints. 1 - Its a gusher. Beware. Half my bottle blew up all over the kitchen. And it just kept going, I had to get 3 glasses. 2 - The mouthfeel. Weak and flat. Cmon! To have such a beautiful beer be almost ruined by being too thin is a damn shame. Regardless, I love this brewery and all their products. Best Belgian themed brewery in America. This is not their best brew, but nothing they do is bad. EDIT: Ok, after I added some of the dregs from the bottom of the bottle, the brett character in the flavor, as well as the mouthfeel, both greatly improved. What a phenomenal beer, once its all said and done.

I think what did it in for me has the odd flavor created by the type of yeast used in the brewing process. Jolly Pumpkin grows the yeast strain within the barrel (some are quite old) and to me it results in a sour, almost bad cheese taste. The aroma is good..very spicy and citrusy...but the taste is dominated by this sourness and that pretty much ruins the rest of the beer.

Luciernaga pours an orange-gold with a massive ivory head.  Lots of belgian spice, especially coriander, and lots of citrus.  Not my favorite style, but probably my favorite of the Jolly Pumkin beers.

The aroma was strongly fruity through the  huge moussy and tall super long lasting frothy head. The aroma had a brett character and a strong presence of oak coupled with spices peppery and earthy. The beer poured into the glass and then kept coming out the top of the bottle, even when half was consumed. The beer was lightly hazy golden and with that super duper head that was second to none. The flavors that came forth as one sucks the head were pure oak. Following that was a nice fruity nature and a strong bittering character. The flavor was earthy and spicy and uniquely interesting. The flavor had a presence of brett coupled to wood and had some citrus, some light caramel and a wheat characteristic. The finish was dry with lasting strong bittering and oak long into the aftertaste and beyond. The body was medium, or maybe more, but the HUGE carbonation was almost too much for enjoyment. A very interesting and tasty beer, this puppy was alive and kicking. 750 ml capped bottle.
user_location: North of Raleigh, North Carolina, USA

text: Big gusher of a bottle. Luckily didnt lose too much to the countertop. Cloudy tangerine with huge chunky head. Aroma- nice oaky funkiness. Taste- high initial sourness that drys quickly. Not really a juicy sourness, more dry woodiness. Little bit of citrus. I think this is the dryest JP beer Ive had. Not high is alcohol, but seems boozy for some reason.

From bottle : Pours a hazy darker amber color, with the biggest, foamiest, whip cream looking head that i have seen, and it stays around FOREVER.  Fairly carbonated.  And wonderful lacing, like a peice of art.  Nose is of yeast and some barnyard smells.  Taste is yeast, and more on the bitter side as opposed to the sweet side.  Has some lemon and sour notes, but the ending is really.....not good.  Kinda a spoiled taste.  Palate is on the thin side, and kinda sticky.  Started out good, but that aftertaste is aweful.

750 ml green bottle. No freshness date seen. A certified gusher here. Contaminated beyond all hope. Sour lactic acid aromas, with lemon juice chaser. Flavors are of lactic acid, vinegar, lemon juice. Go back to the drawing board, Jolly Pumpkin. This beer is not very jolly at all.

750 ml. bottle from Beertopia in Omaha, Nebraska.  Pour is orange gold, with hazy carbonation bubbles.  Big, lasting cream head.  Aroma of grass, sweet yeastiness and the trademark JP barnyard sour funk.  There is also a touch of clean - almost soap in the nose.  Taste is an interesting fruit (apple - pear) sweetness combined with the earthy funkiness.  Some spiciness int he finish, which lingers.  The entire palate is very soft, and drinkable.  Another nice one from Jolly Pumpkin.
Golden. Light ale. Taste of apples. Have had both in bottle and at Michigan Brew Fest. Very nice before it got too funky.

750 mL bottle received via trade with jrob_21.  Pours hazy, effervescent orange with a large, creamy, off-white head, lasting with excellent lacing.  Aroma is average malt (grain, cereal), average hops (grass, flowers, herbs), average yeast (horse blanket, barnyard) with notes of sour cherries, coriander, and pepper.  Full bodied, slick texture, average carbonation, and a bitter finish.  Long duration, light sweetness, moderate acidity, and heavy bitterness.

End of bottle; little head after gushing, unclear orange-ochre beer. Very acidic nose: malonic, cranberry, Bretts to the fore. Soft Bretts taste; some sweet-sour balanc, but uncertain. Failed vinification notes, nutmeg, exotic fruit, sour apples and cinnamon touch. Acid thinning, sharpish MF. Not my idea. JP can do a lot better - beware of the Wyeast ##...

Bottle. Rich amber beer with a huge cream colored head. Wonderful tart aroma with nice spice. Oaky, yeasty, citrus flavor with some backing spice and a vanilla quality. Medium body - high carbonation. LIngering spicy, earthy, vanilla, tartness. The amount of hops surprises me.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2008 Bottle: Like an awakened volcano, this oozes foam, even after 1/3 of the bottle has been poured.  Some serious chemistry going on in this lab in a bottle.  This has a huge spicy nose ... if I knew how to say "oh my" in Flemish, thats what Id write.  Despite all the intimidating presentation, when I finally get a taste, its much more drinkable than I had feared.  Still peppered with earthy spices (holy corriander!), this is subtle enough to allow me to enjoy it without much effort.  (#3239, 12/9/2007)

cracked open the bottle and it fizzed like crazy.  giant dirty white head, lots of bubbles on the tongue.  A burnt orange or caramel color.  smells i pick up are spicy apple, pear, and a little orange.  tastes are of wheat, fruit and spice.

Bright peppery and yeasty aroma.  Slight champagne like qualities.  Golden amber color.  Complex flavors.  Yeast, spice, oak, citrus.  Bright and bitter, sour and lively.  Some cheesiness and lambic qualities.  Lively on the palate.  Rich and strong but not syrupy. Very good.

An excellent beer.  This one is perfect for your summertime festivals.  Especially if you want to impress some friends.  Great aroma, and excellent flavor, just like most of the Pumpkin brews.  I just love this one, and I have quite a few friends that will agree...  Nice cloudy amber color, and great head.  This one is truly nice.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2008 (bottle): Pours a huge foamy head, off-white, good lacing. Extremely cloudy amber color. Fizzy with dark coloring. Aroma of spices, maybe pumpkin, nutmeg. Some flowers, Some sour. Enticing, but not too strong. Fizzy, sour taste. Might be a bad bottle. Some of the spices, but not very flavorful. Reminds me of a flemish sour or a geuze. Soft mouthfeel. More flavor as it warms. More hoppy.

Ok poured this beer and instantly an strange smell filled the air. Yes, Ive had Jolly Pumpkin beers before and liked all of them..... not so much with this one. Aroma is very acidic and tart. Rediculously so, It overpowered any sweetness and spices of the brew. Taste is very much the same. I will say the brew did round out more once is warmed but even still the pungent acid was too much. I found this very strange because I love funky/sour beers. My favorite style is saison afterall! Im pissed about this beer I met the first sour beer that just didnt do it for me. I need to re-rate this later and make sure I just wasnt crazy last night. For now my rating will stand though.

Pours orange/amber with a big foamy white head.  Aroma of oak, musty cellar, coriander and grain. Taste is just a bit tart to start with, add some appple, oak papper, herbal.  Dry finish.  Not as fun for me as there others, but done well none the less.

Bottled. Poured orange with a dirty white foamy head. Aroma reminded me of a sour fart. Kind of like when you walk back into the bathroom after taking a shit 20 minutes prior. Flavor was dry, herbal, and grassy.
[750ml bottle] huge head, nice lacing. i cant name all the smells and tastes, but sour and spicy in a good way. nice dry finish. looking forward to this again. excellent!

Cloudy, amber/gold appearance with a large beige head and very nice lacing.  Intriguing aroma; yeasty, spicy, fruity, earthy, musty.  Taste is vinous, tart fruit, spicy, respectably hopped.  Smooth, medium-to-full bodied, well carbonated mouthfeel.  Dry, long lasting, slightly sour finish.  Thoroughly enjoyable on many levels.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2007 Pours a nice hazy amber with some chill haze. Profuse, absolutely profuse, head. Frothy and offwhite. The aroma is tart apples, pepper, coriander, very spicy, musty, sour.  The flavor was a different story. Strong spice, pepper, coriand4er, fruity, yeasty, nice nice nice. Very lively dry spicy palate and finish. Nice Belgian Ale.

Pours a hazy rusty orange body with a large and billowing offwhite head. Excellent retention and huge sheet lacing. Very floral aroma, with fruit blossoms and spicy hints. Bretts lend a wild and earthy note. Tingly and effervescent mouthfeel becomes satiny at times. Taste is dry herbal hops and a clean dry bitterness. Sour white grapes, limes, woody oak, coriander, and mint add an intriguing complexity. Super drinkability.

750 ml bottle purchased at Johns Grocery in Iowa City. As with other Jolly Pumpkins, this one was a gusher. It poured a hazy golden orange color. Head was off white and tenacious with good retention. A bit of lace was left behind on the glass at the end. Pleasant aroma of oak, clove, coriander, and white wine vinegar. Very effervescent on the tongue. Dry and yeasty up front with a lingering bitterness at the end that is borderline astringent. Spices are evident in the flavor along with a touch of lemon. Mouth feel was on the watery end of the spectrum. Pretty good, but overrated at the 97th percentile.

Not truly my "thing" but I know a good quality beer when I see it. Amazing, relentless foamy head in a hazy light orange. Lots of apple notes in the nose, some balsamic vinegar, yeast, surprisingly dry finish with a bit of puckering astringency. Id say its neither here nor there -- a palatable version of a an extreme style. Spices werent too noticeable. Was expecting a bit more, but not bad at all.
A wonderful belgian ale with the added bonus of JP brewing techniques. What it lacks in malty robustess it more than makes up for with its slightly sour and complex earthy flavors. Clean finish.
26 sept 07.  750mL bottle, green cap.  Deep orange color.  Aroma of astringant malts.  Very yeasty aroma and flavor.  Tartness.  Smells like apple cider vinegar.  Lots of acid.
750 ml bottle: dry, spicey, yeasty earthy.  sour apple, funkky pepery.  sour tangy, acid.  a very unique and amazing beer.  very drinkable.  woul,d buy again.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2011 750 from Sams Blue Light, Durham. This beers hip-hop name is Ol Dirty Bastard. Of all the splendidly funky JP brews, this one may be the funkiest, the Dirt McGirt-est. A hazy amber pour with a giant head, this one has a supremely musky smell, with dry grass, barnyard stank, and sauteed leeks believe it or not. Sour finish to this beauty makes it another winner from the mighty JP!

Pours a clouded amber gold with a decent creme head and a lot of bubbles floating up all over the bottom of my wide glass. Kind of reminds me of fireflies. Nose is very yeasty with a talcy, chalky edge. Flavor is tangy with a bitter tone to it. Also seems to be a pretty firm mineral influence as well. Tart is the name of the game here though as it kicks you pretty good in the back of the mouth. Feel is smooth with a good level of carbonation and bubble hitting you and a decently balanced liquid feel. Overall extremely drinkable. Another fine American produced BPA.

Tallahassee, Fl. -Liquor Loft - 750 ml capped bottle. Murky, deep orange pour with an extremely thick, sturdy off-white head like an root beer float; flecks o sediment floating about. Fresh, spicy aroma with hints of coriander, ripening fruit. Spiciness carries over to the flavor with some nice musty notes, hints of coriander, ripening fruit. Stick to your ribs sourness permeates throughout. Some peppery notes, and a smidgen of licorice. Mouthfeel is very full and thick, silky. Enjoyable.

bottle.  hazy copper pour with frothy off white head.  floral and herbal saison type aroma with touch of citrus and pepper.   lively palate.  very peppery.  baked bread in the finish.  nice hops and complex spice.  dry.

Pours a nice golden color with a very nice two inch rocky head.  Plenty of carbonation racing up the glass and keeping the head going.  Smell is funky and tart.  Taste is very much the same and very good.  Plenty of coriander and spice.  I didnt get that much hops in the taste.  Plenty of tart sweetness though, and I love it.  Mouthfeel is full and smooth.  These JP beers are flooring me.   Great brewer and brewery.

When I opened this bottle it reacted as if it was a champange. Over flow was not from tipping bottle. Lost 1/3 of bottle.  Lacing was  great but very frothy. Head went away quickly but left froth. Very sour, but was not  expected from reading lable. Quite tasty because unexpected experience.  Did not realize sour taste excentuates quiet flavors. 
Frothy lacing goes away quickly which is dissapoiinting. Overall would purchase again knowing the smoothness of drinkablity is there.  Not my favorite type of beer; but for me quite drinkable.

Beer 1 of 2nd Belgian Beer Club Meeting.  Pours apple cider w/ a bright white head.  The nose was yeasty sour and strong.  The taste was sweet, tart, bright and bitter, not bad at all, also a bit fizzy.

750 ml bottle poured a hazy amber with a large lasting ivory head. Aromas of vanilla, spice, fruitiness, barnyard, leather and light carmel. Palate was light bodied crisp and slightly dry. Flavors of carmel, coriander, citrus and good barnyard funk with a crisp dry slightly tart finish.
Beer was yellow-orange with a moderate amount of foam. Sour and oak dominated the aroma and flavor. Very nice! It had a light and soft feeling on the palate.

750 mL bottle. Pours cloudy honey orange with a ton of rocky ivory head. The aroma has lots of peppercorns, some sour lemon, meadow, and cumin. The flavor is quite tart up front. That mild sourness and bit of hops start it off with an edge, but it quickly dulls to a mellow pepperiness. Lots of barnyard character comes out toward the finish. The finish itself is rather dry, and some pleasant light fruit and wood tones stick into the aftertaste. This is some pretty tasty stuff.

Bottle sampled with stegosaurus. Pours a light copper color with a two finger off-white head. Aroma of caramel, sourness, citrus,and some spice.Taste is smooth with citrus, yeast, hops, coriander, and a hint of oakwith a nice lingering finish

Hmmm, I have to say I dont think i cared for this one at all. Nice idea, nice experimentation, but I just didnt care for the results. A bit of a clash, a trainwreck. I give it props for complexity, aroma and flavor both rich with floral spicy hops, a farmy grassy brett, coriander spicings, doughy fruity yeastiness, and a touch of oak. But all that didnt really mesh into something nice. Cloudy copper color, thick stiff white head.

(bottle, thanks Akevitt) Pours gold with a tall white head.  Very funky smell with some oak and spice (coriander) being present.  Spice was present but also alternated with a sour flavor too.  Nice oaky finish.

750ml bottle; Nose has some spiciness including coriander, breadiness, and tartness; lightly hazed copper with a big, glass-lacing, yellowish head; flavor is spices, a little sweet and sour tartness, and citrus hopiness; finish being a combo of lightly bitter and tart!

Unusual and hard to classify.  Sort of a cross between a mild lambic, saison, and Belgian ale.  The aroma has light spice, brown sugar, and lots of wildflowers. Flavor has wild yeast and a good oak flavor, and I am happy it is not ruined by bourbon.  Light spices like in a saison or wit in the finish with yeast.
Thanks to Akevitt for sharing.  Oak spice and sdourness in the nose.  Brown color with a wonderfully spiced body and plenty of oak.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2007 750 ml bottle fron Holiday Wine Cellar: Hazy peach color with a medium off-white head. Yeasty, spicy, tart aroma. Flavor starts sharp and bretty followed by a citrus fruity tartness, some pepper and a bone dry grapefruit rind finish. Light-medium body is tangy with lively carbonation.

Bottle, at London Shindig, August 2007. Hazy blonde colour. Aroma is distinctly musty and woody with some sharp fruity notes. Some earthy farmyard in the flavour with the anticipated sharp bretty notes. But its more fruity and less uncompromisingly sour than I expected. The sourness is more of a moderate bite than a full on blast. All of which makes it an interesting but surprisingly easy drinking beer. Cant deny I was expecting something a little more extreme though.

Beautiful copper-orange in colour, very large off-white coloured head, excellent lacing.  The aroma is of apples, yeast, very bretty, lambicy, floral and spicy.  The flavour is peppery and spicy, yeasty, bretty, some barnyard, earthy, musty, oranges and peaches, light coriander.  Lightly sweet mouthfeel, medium body, high but still soft carbonation.  Finishes long, floral and spicy.  Very Orval like, lots of green apples and brett.  The bottle exploded when I opened it, its a good this I decided not to open it next to my computer.  Absolutely fantastic.
750ml bottle obtained in a trade with <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?U target=blank>OhioDad, thanks Scott.
Opened on July 12, 2007.
No best before date.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2010 
Name: Luciernaga (The Firefly)
Date: June 18, 2005
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, Noog I
Appearance: dark amber, whispy white head
Aroma: sweet malty aroma with a nice amount of spices and double dose of funk
Flavor: sweet and spicy flavor, alcoholic, nice bitter finish

Name: Luciernaga (The Firefly)
Date: September 27, 2006
Mode: bottle
Appearance: cloudy orange with a huge foamy off white head
Aroma: nice light lemon aroma with hints of oak and spicyness
Flavor: lots of oak in the flavor plus a slight touch of tartness, light spicy yeasty character, oak leads to a long bitter finish

Name: Luciernaga (The Firefly)
Date: November 17, 2006
Mode: cask
Source: summits
Score: ii+ to iii
Appearance: opaque orange, small frothy head
Aroma: spicy woody aroma that eventually picks up the orange
Flavor: complex flavor of wood and spices followed by a sharp tartness, nice fruity orange character that grows into being a Jolly Rancher candy with a touch of nice sweetness that I like but Ron would not, well balanced bitterness, upgraded based upon the nice complexity

Name: Luciernaga (The Firefly)
Date: June 27, 2010
Mode: draft
Source: bsp
Appearance: cloudy burnt orange, big creamy beige head, thick drippy lace
Aroma: spicy malt aroma, touch of wood, light tartness
Flavor: dry malt flavor, lots of spicyness, good dose of funk, light oak, balancing bitterness keeps it dry, long spicy bitter finish

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20
Rating: 3.6/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: *** /4

Name: Luciernaga (The Firefly)
Date: December 24, 2007
Mode: bottle
Vintage: 2006
bret character has grown to the point that the bret and oak along with the spicyness become the dominant character with the sweet fruity character a ghost in the background,

(750ml bottle) A gusher, a huge gusher, thank goodness I opened it outdoors.  Coudy, deep amber body topped by large off-white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, oak, funk galore, some sour cherry, light pepper.  Taste is medium sweet, wood, somewhat sour, cherry, light coriander, pepper.  Somewhat dry finish.  Medium body, some effervescence.

Cloudy Dark Mandarin/Apricot Color with Frothy Off White Head. Floral, Spiced and Yeasty Nose. Medium Bodied..Quite Carbonated..Peppery Spiced and Yeasty Flavor Throughout with Notes of Citrus, Spices, Floral Hoppiness.  Spiced Bread. Dry Spiced Aftertaste.
Brown reddish colr....pine scent with an earthy taste. hoppy finish with a hint of coriander and spicy flavor.

750 mL bottle.  Pours hazy amber-red color with a monstrous white head and beautiful lacing.  Subtly sour aroma.  Surprising, strangely peppery/spicy flavor.  Dry finish.  Not my style, but I do like the complexity of it... its good.

In bottle.  smells like a forest, looks like a soft-serve ice cream cone thats been smushed by the first lick.  A beer that changes flavor as you drink it - each sip is an investment in the next.  hops unfold and unfold as beer, strangely, gets smoother and smoother.

Appearance: Nice light amber with a large rocky head that displays great retention.

Smell: Sweet malt with some sharp brett character, citrusy hops and hints of spice.

Taste: Medium hop bitterness on an earthy barnyard background with mild notes of oak. Mildly sweet amd slightly sour, some nice fruity yeasty notes and peppery spiciness complement the lemony citrus flavours quite well.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied, lively carbonation.

Drinkability: Decent Belgian-style pale ale. Pairs nicely with a strong blue cheese.
UPDATED: APR 25, 2009 Cloudy orange with a big white head. Aroma has spices, oak, brett and pineapple. Dry and tart grapefruit and brett flavour. Wonderful complexity and a good tart drinkable beer.
Great beer. Pours out pale ale look. Nice taste hoppy, sweet, with nice finish. Easy drinking belgian style ale.

Bottled. Golden colour, mediumsized white head. Aroma is lots of gruits, gluelike alcohol and some cookies + caramel. Flavour is very sweet nectarish fruity along with some slight alcoholic hints. A lot of vinegar, spices and wooden notes also.

Bottle @ Chris_o shindig 2007. Unclear light to medium amber color with a average, fizzy / creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is sweet vinegar, citrus, fruit, oak. Flavor is moderate sweet, acidic, and bitter with some sourness and a average duration. Body is medium, texture is watey to oily, carbonation is flat.

Bottle.  Hazy, ruddy orange color with a fine cream colored head.  Spicy and citrus laden aroma, slightly funky, with good malts.  Nice grassiness and some light yeast in the background - very light hops.  Pretty funky, but pretty cool.  Hops are more apparent in the flavor and the finish, quite tart, with some spiciness.  I think this beer is quite unique, and I like it.

A great smelling beer: apples, wood, and citrus fruits all showing in the head.  The flavor was a little bit ho-hum, but not unusual for this style.  If I could find it on the map, I would definitely drive to Dexter Michigan to drink this off the tap.  Cheers!

750ml bottle.  Pours a hazy, muddy amber with a monster fluffy white head that sticks around and laces the glass.

The aroma is musty yeast, some grains, wood and spices and a little fruit in the background.

The flavor is some slightly tart and acidic fruits and a hint of spices leading to a noticeable, lightly bitter hop finish.  It has a very dry lingering aftertaste that I cant quite identify.  The mouthfeel is medium with tons of bubbly carbonation.

Overall, a very nice beer.  Its not as sour as JPs other brews.  Its easy drinking, but the aftertaste doesnt quite jive with me.

In the 750 mL bottle from Beertopia. Another homerun from Dexter. This pours a hazy golden brown with a custard-like thick head. It is one of the most beautiful beers that I have ever seen. This beer is like chewing on a pine tree. I simply love the generous use of hops in this. The strong oak flavor is still present, but the hop bitterness takes over the dominant role from the oak barrel in this one. Has that horse barn aroma and is slightly sulfurous. Strong orange and coriander to the nose as well. Drinking this is a delightful experience: the first sip seemed strong and harsh with all that in-your-face bitterness. However, after the third sip, the beer seems super smooth and blended. Sweetness begins to exude out of this thing like crazy. After a few more sips, this gets positively oakey out the wazoo. I get lots and lots of pineapple and grapefruit flavors at the warming finish. After trying this, I am convinced that so many belgian styles that I find hard to enjoy would greatly benefit from a generous use of hops. Damnnit, hops SHOULD be in beer!

A very lively, bubbly brew.  Deep golden color, keeps a nice head with active carbonation.  Flavor is light, palate very soft.  The combination of spices is quite unique.  My first Jolly Pumpkin, and Im very impressed!

Bottled. Bottle gushed. Beer is cloudy medium amber-brown. Head is large, frothy/rocky, off-white, slowly and mostly diminishing but lasting.

Unmistakable tart-untamed JP nose. Malty with light notes of lean biscuit, caramel, toasted grain; Hoppy with moderate lemon zest, herbal resin/pine, green grass; Yeasty with wild, pointy notes of moderate barnyard, horse blanket; Light miscellaneous note of Aspen tree sap/raw wood, round peppery spice, light alcohol warmth.

The flavor is light/moderately acidic, lightly/moderately sweet, lightly bitter with a long, lightly acidic/juicy, lightly sweet trace bitter finish.

The body is light, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2008 750 ml bottle from Holliday Wine Cellar.  Hazy golden amber with a creamy white head.  Amazing aroma of sourness, oak, caramel,  and spice.  Very smooth silky bright and lightly lively palate.   The taste is absolutely fantastic.  A very pleasant alcohol, almost bourbon-like, taste, vanilla, caramel, a warm spiciness and a wonderful indescrible finish.  One of my new favorites.

Bomber split with Tronraner.  Pours a cloudy orange with persistent, tall, fluffy white head. It does that thing where the sides start to collapse and little shapes form. Lacing is pretty slick on this one. Nose is soft indeed with loads of flower notes. I dont know enough about botany to make a meaningful correlation, but it reminds me of flowers in a field with horses and goats wandering around. The flavor is dry. Yep, this is quite dry, but some semi-juicy pineapple notes come out. Lots of floral and herbal notes on this one along with wood, pepper, and champagne. I felt it was similar to the bam biere, but had a bit more juiciness and depth. Nice for the summertime.

This beer is orange and it has a huge fluffy and lasting white head that appeals to my eyes and gets my junk excited. Upfront spicy aroma is so nice. Light crisp and dry this one is. Spicy. Lil bit funky. Got that pepper. Proof that beer doesnt have to be 10% ABV to be complex.

750 ml bottle, drunk from a pilsner glass. Gorgeous opaque caramel color, which sort of doesnt match the taste, but does match the general style. Aroma is moderately malty with a light hop touch. Majority of aroma is must, with some oak and toffee undertones. Head is large, off white,  and slightly rocky. Flavor is moderately acidic, some pepper, and some sourness. Medium body, smooth, quite dry upon finish.  Quite refreshing. Excellent beer.

750ml Bottle:  Aroma is spicy and medium sweet.  Smells of Marsala wine, spices, yeast, champagne, wood,  Piccatta, black pepper, and must.  Poured a light orange/amber color with a huge, dense, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Good lacing.  Cloudy.  Very sparkling.  Flavor is medium sweet and lightly bitter, and very odd.  Tastes of Marsala wine, spices, black pepper alcohol, fruit, and a couple of things I cannot quite identify.  Medium body.  Dry, fizzy texture.  Fizzy carbonation.  Very dry finish.  Overall, not very good.  As I find with most JP brews, very overcarbonated.
Bottle at Chris_o Shindig.  Hazy gold, lasting beige.  God its funky sour, but not over the top.  That is good.  Good funk, good hop, little empty on malts, good lemon.  Excellent.

Sweet, apple, bit funky. Hazy, dark yellow color, off-white head, good lace. Light sweet, citric sourness, nice funky hops and some citrus. Hoppy dry mouthfeel. You have to get used to it but then suddenly it graps you.
Bottled - Chris O shindig 2007 - A hazy light brown coloured beer with an off white head.  The aroma is spritzy funky and peppery.  The taste has brett character with pepper and sour notes.  Not bad.

A Mes rate: 
Bottle at Chris Os Shindig. Dark amber with a white head and lace. Malt and wheat aroma. Very medicinal. Clean hoppy flavour. Grassy and well balanced. Good body. Tasty brew.

750 ml in Duvel glass.  Pours hazy reddish amber with lasting off-white head and lace.  Aroma of fresh bread and sour cherries.  Flavors of cherry tobacco with a dry hoppy bitter clean finish.  Medium-light body, medium-high carbonation.  Refreshing and delicious and not unnecessarily strong.  Maybe Jolly Pumpkins best.   I will drink this again.

poured into tulip.  I was excited for this, it is good, but to me a little dissapointing.  pours a clear brown amber with full fluffy white head.  aroma of wild yeast, spritzy carbonated mouthfull.  very tart and sour to a sour finish.  like sour onion...

750 from West Lakeview.  Muddy brown-orange with substantial white head.  Very nice sour yeast characteristics in the aroma, light spices, lemon, very airy.  Nice lemon sour malt of a brown ale with clove, small alc, woody, refreshing.  Med body with light carb.  I love what they do.

Let me begin by saying that this has such a cool bottle design, it stood out from any other Belgian sitting on the shelf. The ale itself pours a thick white soapy head and a pure orange golden hue. Some noticeable flakes of dust seen floating in equilibrium. The nose is a delightful scent of orange peel, cinnamon, clove and other such spices. Upon first drink this is quite a tart and taste bud shocking brew. In my opinion, this flavor is too unripe and heavily packed with funky yeast that is unknown to my taste. I do think it has a nice touch of spice but overall nothing special to be remembered.
RBSG 07. A gold amber pour that has a light white head. A solid spicy nose that is quite surprising. A sour offering that may be past its prime. Just a bit fizzy.

Hazy darker orange, huge white head. Aroma is citrus, lemon, and a belgian spiciness. Flavor is soapy, with a lot of deep earthy belgian funk to it. Citrus peels of all sorts, orange, grapefruit, lemon and coriander. Dry mouthfeel with a lot of citrus peel bitterness, really too much and Im having trouble getting past the soapiness. An almost floral bitterness as well with nutty notes in the background. Aftertasye is the white part of an orange peel. Different beer in a belgian funky way but Im dissapointed by this one a lot.

poured golden hazy orange.  nice frothy big head. some citrus hop aroma mixed with sour lemon. nice hop characteristic with some pine and grass finishing with a slightly dry tart and sour end. enjoyable, refreshing and solid.

shaggart > 75cl bottle from the foodery. Dark hazy amber with thick, but dispersed cream head. Nice lace. Sweetish nose of flowers and lemon tea with a spicy undertone. Taste to match. Classic Belgian with a buttery twist. Finish of hops, acidic lemon and spice. Noticeably  American. Not bad, but there is better stuff on offer from this brewery.

Poured tangerine with 1 inch white head. Great lacing. Some funky yeast,  and hops in the nose. Incredibly complex and confusing flavors here: mint candy cane, slight sour Brett, coriander. Very herbal and grassy toward the finish. Well-balanced and refreshing. Yet another enigmatic and intriguing beer by JP.

Bottle from South Bay. Dark orange/yellow color on the pour. Aroma is somewhat yeasty with a strong hop presence. Belgian qualities. Sour and yeasty with a strong dry hoppy character. Peppery as well. Quality brew.

pours dark amber with a THICK WHITE head that only disapears in the form of lacing.  The spicy aroma just wasnt for me, but the corriander, oaky, hoppy& spicy flavors were good!  to bad this was only 6.5%. finishs dry

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2007 I was taken aback by this beer.  To me, it was extremely funky and different.  Perhaps it was the combination of all the yeast and spices and oak, but it had a soapy-cheesy flavor to that kinda bothered me.  It was sweet, but very spiced up.  Very different.  Perhaps I was just not appreciating it but I had a hard time getting through the bottle, which I had to finish because my friends wouldnt drink it.

bottle: pours a cloudy golden apple juice colour with a very large foamy white headwith some lacing. aroma is sour, sweet almost green grape like, apple, yeast and some spice, also some lemon i believe. flavour is bitter sour apple funk. a slight spice in the finish. ends very drying and just a bit sour. awesome beer.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy orange/amber with a very large long lasting rocky off-white head that leaves great lacing. Aroma is slightly acidic and spicy with hints of black pepper, rotten citrus peel, vinegar, and spicy & floral hops. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium thin mouthfeel that finishes dry, slightly tart, and spicy. Another wonderfull brew from JP.
Bottle.  Pours an orangish color with a nice head.  Very floral aroma.  Was very peppery which I wasnt a fan of.
Pours a pretty orange brown with a big white head. Spicy aroma with hints of citrus. Pepper and spice dominate the taste with slight malty finish. Lots of carbonation. Wasnt that impressed.

The aroma is floral, yeasty, malty, spicy, and hoppy with some citrus. The appearance is deep amber gold with a nice foamy head. The flavor is just like the aroma with the peppery grains of paradise making their presence known. The palate is typical for the style. Overall its interesting.
quite an exquisite floral hoppy beer, the aroma is citrusy with shades of roses, grass. It looks and pours great, the taste is a tad tart but not sour by any means.

looks like an IPA i guess, smells sour like a jolly pumpkin.  tastes like a jolly pumpkin with a bit of hops... delivers on its promise.  its hard to say much about these because theyre so unique and one dimensional.  good, anyways

I had this one at Dieu du Ciel. The color is golden blonde, with aromas of hops and the taste of coriander and other spicies. There is some bitterness but not long lasting. The aftertaste is very pleasant.

Had this from the cask at Redlight. Poured a cloudy orange color with a thick white head on top. The aroma was yeasty with some citrus fruits and spices. It had that funky smell like almost a musky aroma to it. It tastes of fruits, lots of spice, and a little sour as well. The hops were active in the background as well. It had a lot going on in this one. It is full bodied with a smooth mouthfeel that finishes clean and dry. Another great beer from JP.

Light bronze pour, thick with haze.  A farmish aroma with darting notes of pineapple, coriander and almonds.  Tastes like the juice of a summer peach, rubbed with a tangy ginger vinaigrette.  Some apple and an odd, elusive heavy cream hint.  A fragrant, dry gin finish.  Palate is tart and dry, lacking slightly in spark.  Typical of this brewer for its artfulness and uniqueness.  Thanks Phil!

Pours a beautifully clouded auburn color.  Head is huge and billowy, with peaks much like freshly whipped meringue.  Aroma is spicy and citrusy, some yeast and funk thrown in for good measure.  I find myself wanting to continue to inhale.  Flavor is bright and spicy, with a nice hop "pop" on the finish.  Very amazing beer.

This starts with an aroma of spice, with a certain sourness hiding behind it.  It pours an opaque amber, with a thick white head.  The flavor is peppery, with a hint of dryness there.  Strong presence of spice, with a hint of citrus fruits.  Very light palate. I dont think theres a Jolly Pumpkin beer that hasnt impressed me.

Pours a ruby red color with a big, foamy white head.  Aroma is spicy, sour Jolly Pumpkin funk smell.  The tart, vinegar like smell of a Flemish Sour is here but a little more subdued and appetizing.  Taste is smooth, tart, subtly sour that is flavorful but extremely easy to drink.  Another solid brew from JP.
UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Im not huge on the sour beers, but this one I enjoyed. Didnt find it to be as drinkable as I wouldve liked, but the taste was pretty good.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2007 750ml bottle. Pours hazy reddish copper with an off-white head. Aroma is corriander, yeast, other spices, and sour citrus. Initial taste is spicy, earthy, and corriander followed by a funkiness with horseblanket and barnyard aspects. Finish is spicy hops. Full mouthfeel. Really good.Old rating, just added.   750ml bottle brought back from Chicago. A great belgian style pale ale. Nice malt backing, some spiciness, mild funkiness and sourness, and a big flavorful, hoppy finish. This is an amazing session beer.

Second brew sampled at joebrews Friday evening beer tasting at Cellars. Pours a burt golden yellow brew with a thick foamy off white head with excellent retention. Around of floral hops, citrus (lemon) peel, and some light vanilla. Taste is like a Flemish sour but with more yeast and esters with extra carbonation. Finish is slightly sour and tart with some spice aftertaste.

Murky copper color with a thick head.  Musty coriander aroma and something almost smells pickled.  The taste is extremely bitter and puckering right away.  Dry wheat and lots of spices.  I almost think I can taste cranberries.

Bottle. Pours cloudy copper/amber. A very unique nose: barely any of the bright, citrusy sweetness Im used to in JP beers. Hints of cedar wood, musty basement and sour yeast. Theres a bit of a sourdough bread component, too. Fairly lively carbonation. Nice balance of of spice, sweet and dryness on the palate. Notes of pepper, citrus and new oak. Finishes fairly dry.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2007 Hazy golden-orange pour with a substantial fizzy head.  Aroma has some nice citrus, spice, yeast, and light breadiness.  Taste is a really nice blend of bread, orange, a pleasant hop bite.  This one is really nice.  JP does a great job as always.

Slightly clear orange beer with a white head.  Smells sour and bready.  Almost biscuity.  Almost Saison like flavor.  Sweet and sour.  The finish is really bitter.  I didnt expect such a bitter finish.
Pours a hazy orange color with a white head.  Aroma is wheaty, orange, and spice.  Flavor is spicy, orange, and slightly yeasty.

A cloudy yellow appearance with a large white head. An herbal, lemon, and banana filled aroma. This one was very carbonated and sour with some vinegar and lemon notes. A spicy and sour finish. Nice one.

750 thanks to Beastiefan2k.  Pours a hazy light orange/golden in color.  Medium to large off white head.  Aroma is really nice, spices, musty yeast, citrus fruit, light notes of funk.  Taste is a bit of a letdown in comparison to the aroma.  Up front, spices, light citrus and musty, earthy/spicy, lightly funky yeast, and wood.  The beer seems to suffer in the mid palate where it becomes bland and watery right through the finish.  Perhaps this needed some time to get a bit funkier and tart.

750 poured into a tulip.  The aroma was perfume and coriander.  The flavors were citrus, pepper, apple cider, and fresh bread.  The finish was sweet apple cider and grapes.  This beer was hoppy and refreshing with tons of fruit and spices.  Jolly Pumpkin has been outstanding thus far... now I have to try them all.
Pours a golden color with a white head. Has nice lacing. Hints of sour fruits, spice, and wood. Finishes with a thin tart taste on the tongue. Courtesy of Dragonstout.
Wow this has a great sour aroma with hints of citrus.Pours a hazy orange with a pillowy head. Flavor knocks me over.Sour citrus with hints of spices.Finish was a bit funky, sour like.
Great smelling brew, spices really take the lead here. Funky barnyard is also there, with an Orval like dryness and  crisp hop finish.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2007 Spicy sour aroma, corriander and some citrus.  Pours pale amber with a thick white head.  So good.  Gentle hops, smooth sourness with good spices.  So drinkable, im happy to finish the 750 all by myself!  I love Jolly Pumpkin!

This Belgian Ale pours a deep orange gold color from a 750ml bottle. Large sized white foamy head, long lasting with lots of head retention. Aroma is citrus and spices, mostly orange with some hops and a touch of herbal. A medium to lighter bodied Belgian ale. Malts are fruity and not too sweet. Lots of spices, some yeast, must and barnyard. Dry and crisp, yet there is some sweetness. Lively carbonation. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is crisp and very dry. Aftertaste is a touch sweet with contrasts nicely with the dry finish.

750ml. Bottle
$7.49
Binnys Orland

Luciernaga poured a hazed over orange into my tulip glass. There are many tiny carbonation bubbles rising from everywhere. A 3 finger white microbubbled head appeared on the pour that faded to a 2 finger rockiness. Leaves chunk lacing after each drink.

Smell is dominated by spices but they are in no way overwhelming. Im picking up clove and cardamom that are really nicely balanced. There is that summer field weediness and barn muskiness that are common in saisons. Very refreshing.

Theres is much more malt in the flavor and the spices are more subdued. Nice malty sweetness with a twang on the finish. Its all together spicy and herbal. Very nice. Saison like with a slight sourness and a little more malt backbone.

Mouthfeel is light and lively. Dancing on the tongue. Finishes crisp and dry.

Drinkability is very good. The spices are in no way overpowering. Dry and leaving me wanting more. The lower 6.5% ABV will let you enjoy more than one glass easily.

The Firefly is an extremely goodbeer from Jolly Pumpkin. Definately worth a try if you see it. A nice little twist on a good saison. 

1/21/07

Bouteille de 750 ml obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Odeur doranges et de coriandre avec une pointe de pommes. Apparence: La couleur est orangée avec une faible densité de bulle. Présence dun moyen col mousseux et dune large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût dagrumes et dépices. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement minérale. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence dagrumes en arrière goût. (Rating #1037)

this one was a bit of a gusher. slightly hazy orange/amber with a great fluffy white head that lasts forever. great lacing that sticks to the glass long after the beer is gone. orange coriander aroma with notes of fresh baked bread with light caramelization. nice balance of sweet tart and bitter flavors.sweet/tart orange apple coriander are in the forefront light caramel and bread notes with bitter spicy underling hops rounding out the flavor. sweet tart bitter dry finish. orange coriander apple. lively carbonation. some slightly herbal notes throughout....what i cant quite put my finger on.... medium body. nice. interesting. very reminiscent of orval....but there is something i like about this one a bit more.

750ml bottle, courtesy of jimbowood (big thanks!), pours a murky dark golden with a large pillowy persistent head and great lacing.  Aroma of coriander and a lot of general spices.  Theres a lot going on in the aroma and its very pleasant and familiar but I cant quite place everything there.  Flavor is a bit sweet and a bit hoppy, and works very well.  Notes of orange, apple, a some yeastiness.  Palate is light, lively, with a dry finish; very enjoyable.  This is not what I was expecting, but was pleasantly surprised.

Crap this one gysered on me as the bottle was shaken slightly and the opener I used put a hole in the top which caused the eruption.  What a mess.  Nice yeast and spice aroma. Taste was a little off for me, perhaps from the foam. Still not a bad beer.

Bottle, opened cold and still a gusher!! Pours a cloudy amber with a lasty foamy head. Aroma is spicy, with hints of hops, citrus, bread, wild bacteria, and alcohol. Flavor is tart and moderately acidic, but finish tight and dry. The light hoppy bitterness is present, but doesnt overwhelm. Overall, its a fine brew, but I prefer some of their other offerings.
Bottle from MartinT. Aroma is a saison, if you let it sit for a while it turns into carrot cake. Taste is seriously spicye, carrot and corriander soup, really exciting beer.

Bottle picked up by my pops in MIchigan. Thanks Dad!  Pours a deep orange with a sudsy, pillowy white head similar to Orval. Nose is filled with funky bretty grain and yeast, coriander/citrus, oak, and very, very mild spicey hops.  When served cold, mouthfeel is very sharp and acidic, but this mellows out as the beer warms up a bit. Spicey hops are easily detected.  Nice malt backbone to balance sustained sourness. Dirty socks come full frontal in the palate.  Turned a little watery towards the end and lost some of the bretty touches that are so apparent in the nose.  This is still a very nice brew, but I think I enjoyed the grand reserve a little more.

Malty aroma with some sweet scents.  Dkar brown with red hues.  Medium palate.  Very much like a barleywine I thought with sweet flavors and caramel malts prevailing over the hints of hops and sourness.

Lots of sourness dominates the aroma.Pours a medium copper with a medium off white head.Has a funky sourness with a big malt backbone in the flavor.Mouthfeel is a little thin with some yeast in the finish.

hazy, murky orange color. lots going on in the aroma, coriander, yeast, orange, lemon, apple, a hint of mint. flavour is beautiful, sweetness with apples, and a slight tarness that is followed buy a loverly bitterness that reminds me a lemonade. as the beer wamrs up, its very much tart like a lambic. mouthfell is so smooth, and lots of lovely gentle carbonation. outstanding beer!
Wonderful smell. Rather spicy with a lightly sour twinge. Light, malty, sour flavor. Bubbly mouth feel.

Bottle (thanks to Jrob_21) poured a clear gold color with a nice fizzy white head. Aroma was hoppy, spicy, yeasty and had a small hint of oak as it warmed. The taste was smooth with a fair amount of hop bitterness and flavor. The spices come trough nicely and knock down the belgian yeast strain flavor. Not my fav. style, but this one was very enjoyable.
Bottle. Cloudy golden colour with a nice white head. Aroma of sourness, acid and little youghurt-like. Flavour of malt, alcohol and someway little sour and acid. Not the best taste i had.

750 ml bottle, pitted this up against the grand reserve firefly.  Sour funnky aroma, vinegar, vegatable, tomato.  I cant get over this bad funky aroma.  Tall white head, orange, hazed color.  Sour fruit flavors, very complex.  Hops, dry apples, oak, alcohol, creamy funky, Im not enjoying this as much as other JP beers.  Ill give it a second try some other time.

Bottle sampled. pours light amber with some hazyness, and with an off-white head. Aroma of fruit, citrus, spices, hops, and belgian style yeast. The flavor is sweet, fruit, citrus, spices, belgian yeast.

Cloudy dark amber-oangeish hue, with a thick beige head, leaving laces, yeasty, fruity nose, with a hint of wild yeast brettanomynces, a flowery hop leafiness accent, toasted malt, faint coriander spiciness and a citrusy note in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a yeasty, juicy floral hop character, with a brettanomynces accent, some leafy, grassy and piney notes, a citrus fruit, dry wineyness, subtle coriander spiciness, leading towards a sweet mild tartness, hop bittering finish.

Tons of green apple flavor.  I dont know if this is a flaw in the batch or if its supposed to taste like this.  Its definitely not unpleasant.  Some pear and white grape are certainly there as well.  Corriander.  Very wet mouthfeel, but a dry finish.  Big complexity.  A little sour and a little tart.  Fresh and crisp.  The true strength of a JP beer is the freshness and this delivers.  Hard to pinpoint flavors, but very complex.  Not quite funky, but just a nice sourness.  What a great beer.  Really beyond my ability to describe it.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2009 750ml, thanks to holdenn for this, pours cloudy amber with fluffy white head. nose is really bretty and funky, lots of oak, vanilla, and subtle coriander. flavor has really nice brett, vanilla, coriander, lemon, and white grapes. finish is very dry. mouthfeel is full and creamy. this is a delicious beer. 4.1. 

8/31/09, 07 bottle aged 2 years. this was divine. a greatly balanced yet beautifully bretted out version of this brew. lots of vanilla and oak with funky chesse notes and white wine notes. dry finish thats slightly finish. wow awesome stuff and this aint getting better with more age. 4.2.

Bottle - 750ml. Light amber body with low carbonation and a lasting off-white foamy head. Sharp hoppy aroma that carries herbal and fruity (mainly grapefruit) notes. Very well balanced hoppy taste that ends with a long bitter/sour finish. Very nice!

Clear orange/amber with a huge head. Lots of lacing as the head turns rocky. Aroma of Belgian yeast, peppery spices, coriander, sweet fruit and oak. Tang of fruit in the taste. Moderately sweet, moderately sour and lightly bitter. Light to medium body. Complex, and very good.

Bouteille de 750 ml, bu à Dieu du Ciel. Blonde dorée pale, petit collet. arome légé dhoublon avec des notes intéressantes de gingembre, de coriande et dagrumes. Goût légé et plaisant dhoublon épicé aves un soupson dagrumes, finission sec.

Sampled at the O-Town throwdown. Pours hazy orange to copper with nice off white head. The aroma is mostly tart. The flavor attacks my taste buds with tart sourness that tails into some tart citrus notes.

Nearly clear dull orange with a firm white head. Clear enough to see the other side of the glass, Has a gem like quality to the look of it. Tart and spicy with noticable citrus. Smells like a Saison. Sour, slightly astringent, puckering and dry. Finishes bitter. Quite bold in flavor but still balaced nicely.

Poured a light, cloudy orange with ample head. The aroma was full of citrus, coriander, and some yeast funkiness. The taste was pretty interesting, in that it was dominated by citrus and pepper; quite the combination. It finished pretty dry and citrusy. I shared this with some friends and we werent really sure what to think. Its certainly quite different than any beer I had previously tasted and I enjoyed it for what it was.

Pours a hazy golden orange with a very thin light white head.  Some acidic tannins mixed with light citrus show up in the nose in true JP form.  Taste is somewhat spicy and sour mixed together.  I get some sweet malts, lemons, and yeast blended together to form the main character of this brew.  Ive been wanting to try this one for a long time and it didnt disappoint.  i liked it.

Bottle.  Ive had gushers before, including a few memorable ones in Belgium, but this takes the cake.  And with the big bottles, theres a lot to gush.  Pale amber/copper body with, naturally, a huge, sticky, lacing, off-white head.  Rather spicy nose, lots of coriander and orange peels.  Yeast with some light fruitiness.  Taste is very dry, lightly woody, with yeast and faint bg fruitiness.  Finish and aftertaste are very dry and spicy with light caramel and medium bitterness.  Medium body with light-medium citric sourness and accents from the (relatively low) alcohol.  I tend to like dry, sour, spicy beers quite a bit, and this one is very easy to drink in quantity.  On the whole, good, and slightly interesting, but not worth the considerable trouble.

Light orange color with big white head.  Funky citrus and yeast aroma.  Taste is pungent up front and mellows out to a smooth, slightly bitter swallow.  The power of the aromas and tastes at first are a little offsetting but interesting for a beer.

(big thanks to bbb63 for the hookup on this.)cloudy orange with a thick off-white head.the head sits around for many moments after the pour.as it sits it leaves thick webbing on the glass.the aroma mixes up citrus,funk,coriander,and caramel malts.flavor is a mix of the aroma.plus some seltzer water,salt,and maybe a bit of pear.not as fizzy and light in the palate as the reserve.pretty nice stuff.

Aroma:Citrus fruit,orange,acidity...
Appearance:Hazy orange,good lacing white head...
Flavor:Very citrus,spicy,fruity...

Grapefruit, orange peel, noble hops and more citrus fruits in the aroma. The body is a golden brown color toped by a fluffy white head. Lightly sweet bread like malts are accompanied by corriander and black peppercorns. Soft mouthfeel. Nice stuff.

Pours a slighty murky medium aber color, with a light tan almost white head. Cascading bubbles are cool. THe smell is of a light Belgian, not over powering but noticable. Up front it smells like cirtisy(sp?), this may be the first time I actually smelled apple. Very tart taste to it, but not over powering. A little over carbonated IMO. Really fizzy at the begining, finishing dry. THis is a very good brew, just a few things keeping it from being great.

750mL bottle.  Murky golden orange with a massive rocky white head.  Perfumey spice, earthy floral hops, and bretty phenols in the aroma.  Slight citrus-tinged maltiness with peppery spice.  Floral tones emerge with a tart character midpalate.  Residual tartness in the finish with a large yeasty component and citrus rind.  Mouthfeel is a light medium, somewhat dry.

From a 750 ml. capped bottle with a blurb along the right side of label, poured carefully to leave the yeast in the bottom of the bottle.

Poured a bright reddish orange with a fluffy, foamy head, decent retention.

Aromas of earthy, musty yeast, coriander, spices, tart fruitiness, and sweet pale maltiness.

Good active carbonation and a crisp, dry, tart, velvety carbonated smooth light bodied mouthfeel.

Pleasant sour, tart taste, orange, lemon and pears, coriander, grains of paradise, a white peppery spiciness, a little candied sugariness that adds a subtle sweetness, herbal, the hops have a light bitterness, a flash of alcohol towards the end, and a dry malty, yeasty finish.

Another well made ale from Jolly Pumpkin, well worth trying.

Pours orange with a tall cream colored head that is very thick. Sweet nose with a earthy spice to it, light straw character, orange peel, and soft hops. Very high carbonation really brings the beer to life strengthening the spices. The lemony sourness builds in the finish blending well with the spiciness of the yeast strain. Dry and oaky flavor up front that gets balanced against the sourness.

Hazy orange-gold pour with a nice dense and lasting white head and good lacing.  Lots of sour lemon, grapefruit, and orange aroma with hints of spice.  Loads of funk and citrus in the flavor with a very light and delicate malt and candi sugar balance, dry an lightly piny on the finish.  Medium body, lively carbonation, and dry champagne like finish.
High carbonation, great funky aroma. The flavor and aroma are much the same as the other Jolly Pumpkins. Good beer, maltier than the Otono.

Hazy orange color - bubbly with a lively fluffy head.  Aroma is spicy - slight farmhouse, a slight hint of orange & coranger.  Flavor is lively - lots of spiciness but not overwhelming.  Nicely balanced and well crafted.

Hazy orange pour belies an overzealous white head, billowing ever nearer the rim of my tall glass. Lacing left behind by the quickly diminishing head is thick and webbed. Aroma is sweet and spicy, with notes of freshly concocted Brettanomyces, contorted fruits and vegetables(in no way an insult to the lovely scent), coriander and lemon peel, sweet malt and caramel atop a base of vanilla custard. Cool. Flavor is almost as diligent at riling the senses, with tastes of peppery fruit, farmhouse funkiness, more brett and orange, with a touch of fresh mint and fresh flowers. Palate is extremely smooth even though it has a grainy feel in the back of the throat. Finishes with compounded spiciness and a dry hop crunch. Throughout a glass of this wonderful beer, I cant help but wonder how much Id probably enjoy this were it aged in a port barrel. Yummy stuff.

What a fucking gusher!  Oh my god, I put my thumb over the top (unsucessfully) and sprayed an awful mess between the living room and the bathroom.  Oh well, at least it smells nice.  Pours a cloudy orangey amber to copper with a big healthy head (duh, with all that carbonation).  Theres some sandy looking particles settling on the bottom of my gladd, knocking this down in looks.  The nose is very nice though.  No sign of nonintentional infection.
