text: Bottle pours hazy caramel, large foamy off-white head, with wonderful lacing.   Soft sweet nose, slight corriander, hints of passionfruit, yeasty/bready.   Light floral and tropical fruit on the tongue, minor sourness, not as sweet as I would have thought based on the aroma.   This is followed by a dry bready/earthy flavor.   Body and mouthfeel are both full to medium.   Finishes with a bit of apple skin, lightly spiced, and rather yeasty/bready.   Little bit of an astingent kick at the very end.    Good, but a little sharp in some spots.   Thanks goes out to CaptainCougar for the trade!

Large white head, good retention and a healthy dose of lace left behind. Hazy light copper/orange hued brew. Lightly spicey nose, oaky, whiskyish aromas dominate. Medium body, velvety texture. Dry woody notes, lightly fruity. Pleasently spicey, coriander with a touch of vanilla. The barrel aging of this beer adds a neat contrast to the spices making it highly drinkable! A very enjoyable and interesting B/A brew. Finish is dry, woody and lasting. Thanks so much John!

Bottle. Thanks to wohlfs for this! Clouded amber body with a small creamy white head. Aroma is very floral and spicy with light wood, yeast, grains and light maltiness. Taste is very "musty" and floral with moderate spiciness, toasty malts, dough, light fruits and wood. Very herbal notes to this as well. The wood is like fresh cut wood. Body is medium with full carbonation, and a pleasant dry end. Finish is more floral notes, yeast, wood, light spices along with dried fruit and dough.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2007 Bottle. Head is initially large, frothy, rocky, off-white, fully lasting. Body is hazy medium amber, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain), lightly to moderately yeasty (cobwebs, barnyard), with notes of autumn leaves, wood, clove, lemon/orange zest, nutmeg. Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, velvety/creamy texture, lively carbonation. Hate to say it, but "just another" sourish, dry Jolly Pumpkin brew. Theyre becoming kind of samey (the added spices dont stick out much, so this is similar to Roja, etc.), although almost always very tasty.

750ml bottle. Sour and spicy aroma. It pours a cloudy golden with great head and lacing.  It has a nice bitterness up front with  interesting vanilla and herbal flavors. I thought it was a little thin for the amount of bitterness but overall a good beer that would age well. Thanks Dewbrewer!

Just about as good a saison as I have ever tasted.  A soft marshmallowy maltiness in the aroma.  A thick white head with lots of lacing.  A peachy color and a little cloudy.  Some nice alcohol warmth if you hold it on your tongue.  I am all about balance -- thats what I look for in a beer and this one has it plenty.  Some solid malt character but enough hops to make it a great mix.  It whafts to the back of the throat long after the swallow.  Some sweet toffee.  Absolute brilliant.

750 ml bottle joyously downed with MartinT, tiggmtl and Rastacouere.  Dull brassy/coppery complected, lightly hazy with a thick lasting dollop of foam...huge spicy-sweet nose, vanilla thyme and oak present amidst the thick malt...mouthfeel absolutely gorgeous, creamy-soft and pillowy, you want to lie down in it...flavors rough and farmy, alcohol slightly present with sour fruits and pepper...a magnificent treat.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2007 The Lure:A towering foam outgrowth leaves islands of lacing all over. Whispering wooden barrels delicately suggest engaging conversation to the flowery hops and grains of paradise. Wild yeast is perfectly integrated for tantalizing results.br>

The Festivities:Dry oranges, peaches and apricots are fabulously linked by the wooden dryness component of the barrel aging. Coriander milkiness seduces, and is frothy carbonation is lively and authentic, this is as drinkable as it can get, while remaining rustic. The remarkable brett wilderness is never aggressive, only a competent companion amongst others to render more complexity. Stunning. 

Transcendence:On the French countryside, the soup of the day is always straight out of the garden. And boy is it lovely.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2006 Oak, vanilla, nutty marzipan and market-fresh vegetables in the aroma along with a beautiful brett character.  Hazy, burnished golden-copper coloured body with decent off-white head that recedes to generous and lasting fine-bubbled cover with some nice lacing.  Earthy, musty, light barnyard, but clean tasting with a nice peppery spiciness and some minty notes and some flowery hops.  Brett character is also very apparent in the flavour and lingering in the aftertaste.  Fair bitterness in the finish.  Beautiful soft texture and mouthfeel with fine-bubbled carbonation that stimulates the tongue and opens the tastebuds.  I just want to bathe in this one.  Bottle enjoyed with MartinT, muzzlehatch and Rastacouere.  Original rating (8-3-8-5-16=4.0), resampled Mar-06 and bumped the score up dramatically.

Slightly hazy orange. White, soft, sticky head boasts more than honest lacing. Never heard of aroma, cedar juice. What are those hops? They feel german in a way.. theyre a pure pleasure, a treasure. Very woody, subtle, elegant. Sprucey orange juice uncovers a spicy medley and a shot of vanilla. Minty, musty, earthy. Enjoyable belgian yeast, dry (pencil shavings) and bready. Original leafiness lasts and lasts in a straw-like bitterness, sandy and earthy. Yum. Incredibly mellow palate, superb carbonation, soft medium body. Unique and tasty, Jolly Pumpkin has become in no time a serious rival to any farmhouse beers producer and trying those beers is mandatory for any amateur of the genre, a complement to beer culture.

75cL bottle.  Pours a cloudy, golden.  The aroma has some mineral smell, big yeast, flowery and fresh.  Very nice when swirled.   The flavor has some unexpected bitterness and tannins but it is a tasty brew with some spicy notes but nothing dominating.  It has a slightly bitter finish that would probably smooth with aging.  It might be a bit thin for the flavors.  Tasty beer.  Thanks for the bottle, Bob!!!!!

yeasty aroma of fruit, spices, very light oak.  soft orange with a little light brown in color, small head with good lace.  taste is spicey, light fruit, soft everywhere.   late peppery yeast.  light hops, yeasty, very very nice.  so velvety

Sampled lightly chilled, December 2004
Pours a hazy light amber to copper color, the haze is entirely a chill haze as this beer was quite clear before I chilled it.  It is topped by a tan head that is quite thick, frothy and creamy at the same time.  As I was pouring it, I thought that I got some aromatic notes of oak, but more the woody component, which I was not really expecting.  As I go in for a more extended sniff, I get a complex mix of wood, orange peel, cobwebs, and a bit of herbal character.  There is a definite dominant note here that I cannot quite place, it is sort of spicy, yet combines all of the above descriptors as well.

My first taste; this beer stats out soft and smooth, and then moves to a certain mouth coating fullness, it then finishes with a slightly sharp astringency, yet throughout it remains refreshing.  The interesting aroma from the nose is in the taste as well, and there is a certain tannic backbone here as well, perhaps the contribution from the barrel fermentation.  This beer is quite interesting, and certainly not at all what I expected.  The taste is subtly spicy with soft, smooth notes of orange, grass/ hay, ginger, and coriander.  Ah that is what it is, the coriander is what I was sensing in the nose.  And I also see that grains of paradise was used too, which also makes sense as I always felt that this contributes a sort of dusty dried ginger type thing to a beer.

As it begins to warm up I start to get and enticing note of green beans that have just been spritzed with lemon  in the nose.  And despite it sounding weird, this beer really does evoke thoughts of chewing on old dusty cobwebs.  I really like the fact that this beer has a certain fullness and body to it, even though it is relatively low in alcohol, it gives this beer a certain richness that is quite appropriate for a December evening.  There is a certain soft creaminess to this beer that I am really digging, it just envelopes my mouth in an extravagant celebration of taste.

Despite all I have said, this is currently lacking that certain... something, that would put this over the top, but given Jolly Pumpkins stated goals and practices, I have a feeling that this will become more complex and challenging (this is definitely a good thing) over time.  And please dont let my statement make you think that this beer is not superb, this is a beer that demands to be contemplated, quite the tasting brew, and I am enjoying the complexity that is inherent in this tasty brew.  To finish, I have got to say "damn I wish I lived in Michigan."

Much appreciation extended to wohlfs for sending me the Jolly Pumpkin lineup! 

Rating # 640
Amazing! The body of this beer is a deep cherry wood amber, and the head is a mountain of off-white rocky cream; a big beautiful presentation in my tulip glass. The aroma is a full floral bouquet of fresh spring flowers. It is rather perfumEE, with strong cedar wood suggestions. A walk-in cigar humidor with fresh flowers under your nose. The flavor brings a complex intermingling of musty, doughy Belgian yeasts, with mention of citrus-like, piney, woodsy American hops. There is a large suggestion of freshly ground black pepper corns and a lighter hint of rosemary. The malt and hop is so delicately intertwined it adds a marvelous old world complexity. Towards the finish the spicier flavors of coriander and clove hit the palate, followed by orange and lemon then finalized by a tart hoppy / yeasty / oaky / citrusy BLISS! This is truly a unique, complex, and intriguing creation; one that firmly lives up to the self described expression Artisan Ale!

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2005 spicy hops in the aroma underneath a distinct cheese aroma that smells delicious, orange with an incredibly tight cream colored head, very yeasty and spritzy with  lots of coriander and lingering spicy hops, a unique and refreshing beer

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2005 Update3/26/2005With some age this thing has only gotten better. Quite murky, orange body. The head is almost meringue in its consitency. As it collapses it forms peaks much like meringue. Ever so slightly off-white. Lacing is beautiful, big thick sheets cling to the glass. The aroma does not exhibit the barrel aging as much as the other Jolly Pumpkins I have had. Spicy, orange rind, coriander, and lots of yeasty character. The flavor shows more the barrel-aging, mediium oak and a good dose of hoppy bitterness. Malts come in next then the alcohol sneaks up. Everything comes together very well with this one. The body is medium, bitter throughout. Nice lingering finish. Wow, the best of the Jolly Pumpkin lot so far. Very nice.

light amber color...hazy orange with medium off-white head; aroma is full of sugars  and spices; flavor is abundant of spices also, with a hint of orange rind and lemon; palate was smooth, with a very easy mouthfeel

Pours a lightly hazy copper bronze with a frothy and well-lacing white head.  Aroma is a complex mix of rich oak, sweet carapils malt, bready Belgian yeast, and a hint of spice.  Starts with a mild caramel malty sweetness turning toward a dry spiced and musky oak finish.  Nice balance throughout, but could use a little more complexity and the barrel aging oak could be toned down just a touch, but otherwise, this is a very enjoyable and drinkable brew!  Many thanks to wohlfs and Silphium!

Cloudy medium orange body, thin/medium off-white head.  Spicy nose with sweet caramels and citrus, quite perfumey and sugary, with oak/vanilla notes.  Oak barrels are quite evident in the flavor in the form of vanilla.  Pepper and coriander, citrus and a hint of honey contribute to give this beer a cookie dough gestalt before the strong tannic finish.  Nicely complex although its a bit "hot" out of the barrel.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2006 Wow!!! much deserved re-rate, didnt have any kind of an appreciation for something like this in my early days on the site. Cloudy orange/light amber, significant amount of yeast considereing its the top of the bottle. Lots of carbonation, huge off-white head made of tiny bubbes. Very chewy/bready yeast character in the nose, citrus zest, lots of sour funk in the background, wood character brings a slight smokiness. Lots of flavors intertwined, light orange/citrus zest, again nice chewy bread. Paradise shows heavily towards the finish, with a nice sour twinge that puckers the mouth. Smooth creamy mouthfeel, comes alive on the tongue, due to carbonation. Another fine brew from Ron!!

cloudy amber--big frothy beige head.  yeasty estery aroma, spicy.  very tart with a strangely spicy/peppery finish that sticks to my tongue.  orange and coriander, with a very dry finish.   not particularly hoppy but kind of bitter.  an interesting take on the belgian style.

Visited Jolly Pumpkin brewery last week and picked up a selection of their brews.  I tried Luciernaga first.  Poured beautifully.  Large head of small bubles.  Smelled pretty good. Maybe not hoppy enough , and with a peppery aroma.  Treated the palate nicely but really did not enjoy the peppery aftertaste.  Just didnt seem to go with the rest of what was going on.  Definitely worth a try though.  They really have an impressive facility that is dedicated to traditional methods. Cheers!

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2007 Bottle:  Nice aroma of citrus, apples, lemons,  moderate vanilla, floral hops, and light spice.  Pours a transparent orangish-amber with a large white head that has some staying power.  The flavor starts with a nice mixture of citrus and light brett sourness that lingers  throughout.  There is a touch of vanilla in the background, but it becomes stronger as it warms and blends very well with the bret.    Corriander blends well in the finish with light floral hops and a hint of oak.  The carbonation is rather lively and is initially a tad prickly, but seems to mellow over time to become much softer.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2005 Im thinking I dont understand this one, but thanks for the opportunity Michael!  Pours orange, translucent and with a frothy white head.   Aroma is some what IPA ish in that is citrus, grapefruit, but the sourness and breadish yeast aroma separates it.  Flavor is acidty, candi, and tart. Finish is fairly dry.

Pours a clear caramel color with a huge fluffy white head.  Aroma is just amazing.  A perfect array of aroma and flavor, caramel, spice, alcohol, fruit.  Smooth and really nice wintery feel to this one.  Body is so nice, man oh man this is a really good beer.  Jolly pumpkin is really impressive.
bottle, golden orange in color, medium off white head, medium lacing, definitely a little dry with a slight fruit and hoppy finish.

Bottle.  Orange colored with a slight haze.  Nice off-white head fades leaving a small ring at the glass edge.  Good lacing.  Aroma is a little spicey, some malt and hop aromas mix also.  Mouthfeel is pleasant, a little dry with moderate carbonation.  Coriander is present but not overwhelming.  Fairly hoppy at the finish.  Much more so than the other offerings from this brewery.  Very nice.

Foggy orange. Fat, white meringue  deposits intricate, caked-on lacing all over the glass. Vibrantly tangy Hallertau aroma with notes of rosehips, coriander, candied ginger, and sweet orange peels. Chock-full of bubblegum, banana, and brashly phenolic esters, as well. Lush, velvety carbonation. Quenching, initially, with a creamed malt dollop and zesty hop splash. Remarkably bright and composed hop profile. Sneaky alcoholic warmth bolsters the coriander sting. Slowly intensifying heat from the Grains of Paradise yields soft notes of citrus and ginger. Leathery yeast gains more astringency and the sweetness becomes exaggerated as it warms. Boldly sweet, crackery malts are underlined with bananas & cream kissed with vanilla and pie crust. Utterly divine peppery yeast character fuses with the creaminess and continues to enhance the flavor. Finishes explosively juicy and poignantly hoppy, with  a blend of passionfruit, bananas, and yeast. Touch of tannins numb the tongue long after its departure, although the oak flavor is less prominent. Serving this slightly cold (45F), will suppress the sweetness and allow the bright hop character to shine. Saying this is refined, is an understatement. Thanks, Prof!

text: UPDATED: JAN 21, 2006 Rerate AGAIN: this is just a killer beer. Rerate: the Spiciness has migrated to the aroma, with some alcohol thinning what you can get nasally as well. Dropped a notch there. But the flavors are so much more melded and mellow, with still a crescendoing spiciness over the long pull - much improved, along with the overall score. Original: Orangey-amber with a lasting head of a few mm. Quite spicy nose; sweet but very peppery, some earthiness - very deep and natural. Mucho effervescence in the mouth leads to the impression of a medium to thin body; certainly this is the slimmest of JPs beers as you drink it. Favors are very spicy now - lots of coriander for sure, a good dose of alcohol punch even at 6.5%, cinnamon too. When fully warm (and I mean sit-out-for-an-hour-in-a-glass warm), a very subtle undercurrent of cane sugar appears. This needs a bit of mellowing, I think, but it should only take two months if the maturation of its brethren is any indication. This brewery is also really maturing along with its beers. Cheers to Ron Jeffries.
